member.summary: Gets or sets whether automatic heartbeat checking is enabled. Default is true.

member.name: P:NFSLibrary.NfsConnectionHealthOptions.HeartbeatInterval

member.name: P:NFSLibrary.NfsConnectionHealthOptions.UnhealthyThreshold

member.name: P:NFSLibrary.NfsConnectionHealthOptions.HealthCheckTimeout

member.name: T:NFSLibrary.NfsConnectionOptions
member.summary: Configuration options for NFS client connections.

member.name: P:NFSLibrary.NfsConnectionOptions.UserId
member.summary: Gets or sets the Unix user ID for authentication.
member.remarks: Default is 0 (root).

member.name: P:NFSLibrary.NfsConnectionOptions.GroupId
member.summary: Gets or sets the Unix group ID for authentication.
member.remarks: Default is 0 (root).

member.name: P:NFSLibrary.NfsConnectionOptions.CommandTimeoutMs
member.summary: Gets or sets the command timeout in milliseconds.
member.remarks: Default is 60000ms (60 seconds).

member.name: P:NFSLibrary.NfsConnectionOptions.CommandTimeout
member.summary: Gets or sets the command timeout as a TimeSpan.
member.remarks: This is an alternative to CommandTimeoutMs for more readable configuration.

member.name: P:NFSLibrary.NfsConnectionOptions.CharacterEncoding
member.summary: Gets or sets the character encoding for file names.
member.remarks: Default is ASCII encoding.

member.name: P:NFSLibrary.NfsConnectionOptions.UseSecurePort
member.summary: Gets or sets whether to use a secure port (less than 1024) for the local binding.
member.remarks: Default is true. Some NFS servers require connections from privileged ports. Setting this to true may require elevated privileges on the client.

member.name: P:NFSLibrary.NfsConnectionOptions.UseFileHandleCache
member.summary: Gets or sets whether to enable file handle caching.
member.remarks: Default is false. When enabled, file handles are cached to reduce round trips to the server. This can improve performance but may cause issues if files are modified by other clients.

member.name: P:NFSLibrary.NfsConnectionOptions.NfsPort
member.summary: Gets or sets the NFS server port.
member.remarks: Default is 0, which means use the portmapper to discover the port. For NFSv4, the standard port is 2049. Set this to a non-zero value to connect directly without using the portmapper.

member.name: P:NFSLibrary.NfsConnectionOptions.MountPort
member.summary: Gets or sets the mount protocol port (NFSv2/v3 only).
member.remarks: Default is 0, which means use the portmapper to discover the port. Set this to a non-zero value to connect directly without using the portmapper. This is ignored for NFSv4 which doesn't use a separate mount protocol.

member.returns: A new NfsConnectionOptions instance with the same values.

member.returns: A new NfsConnectionOptions instance.

member.name: P:NFSLibrary.Protocols.Commons.NFSPermission.UserAccess
member.summary: Gets or sets the user (owner) permission bits.
member.remarks: Values: 0=none, 1=execute, 2=write, 3=write+execute, 4=read, 5=read+execute, 6=read+write, 7=all.

member.name: P:NFSLibrary.Protocols.Commons.NFSPermission.GroupAccess
member.summary: Gets or sets the group permission bits.
member.remarks: Values: 0=none, 1=execute, 2=write, 3=write+execute, 4=read, 5=read+execute, 6=read+write, 7=all.

member.name: P:NFSLibrary.Protocols.Commons.NFSPermission.OtherAccess
member.summary: Gets or sets the other (world) permission bits.
member.remarks: Values: 0=none, 1=execute, 2=write, 3=write+execute, 4=read, 5=read+execute, 6=read+write, 7=all.

member.name: P:NFSLibrary.Protocols.Commons.NFSPermission.Mode
member.summary: Gets or sets the permission mode as an octal integer (e.g., 755, 644).
member.remarks: Returns -1 if all permission bytes are 0xff (unset).

member.name: M:NFSLibrary.Protocols.Commons.NFSPermission.ToString
member.summary: Returns a string representation of the permissions in rwx format.
member.returns: A string showing user, group, and other permissions separated by " | ".

member.name: T:NFSLibrary.Protocols.V4.NFSv4
member.summary: Implements the NFSv4.1 protocol for network file system operations.

member.name: M:NFSLibrary.Protocols.V4.NFSv4.Connect(System.Net.IPAddress,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Text.Encoding,System.Boolean,System.Boolean,System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Establishes a connection to an NFSv4.1 server.
member.param: The IP address of the NFS server.
The timeout in milliseconds for client operations. Uses 60000ms if set to 0.
The character encoding to use. Uses ASCII if null.
Whether to use a secure port for communication.
Whether to enable file handle caching for improved performance.
The NFS server port. Use 0 to discover via portmapper, or 2049 for standard NFSv4 port.

member.name: M:NFSLibrary.Protocols.V4.NFSv4.Disconnect
member.summary: Disconnects from the NFSv4.1 server and releases session resources.

member.summary: Gets the optimal block size for read and write operations based on server capabilities.
member.returns: The block size in bytes, capped at 65236 bytes.

member.name: M:NFSLibrary.Protocols.V4.NFSv4.GetExportedDevices
member.summary: Gets the list of exported file systems from the NFS server.
member.returns: A list of exported device paths. NFSv4.1 returns only the root "/" as a single export.

member.name: M:NFSLibrary.Protocols.V4.NFSv4.MountDevice(System.String)
member.summary: Mounts the specified NFS device.
member.param: The name of the device to mount.
member.exception: Thrown when the NFS client is not connected.

member.name: M:NFSLibrary.Protocols.V4.NFSv4.UnMountDevice
member.summary: Unmounts the currently mounted NFS device.

member.summary: Retrieves a list of items (files and directories) in the specified directory.
member.param: The full path of the directory. Use "." for the root directory.
member.returns: A list of item names in the directory.
member.exception: Thrown when the NFS client is not connected.
Thrown when access is denied or other NFS errors occur.

member.summary: Retrieves a list of items in a directory using a file handle.

member.returns: A list of item names in the directory.

member.summary: Retrieves the attributes of a file or directory.
member.param: The full path of the item.
Whether to throw an exception if the item is not found. Default is true.
member.returns: The attributes of the item, or null if not found and throwExceptionIfNotFound is false.
member.exception: Thrown when the NFS client is not connected or other connection errors occur.

The permissions to set on the directory. If null, defaults to 777.

member.name: T:NFSLibrary.Protocols.V4.RPC.Bitmap4
member.summary: Represents a bitmap for NFSv4 attribute masks.

member.name: F:NFSLibrary.Protocols.V4.RPC.Bitmap4.Value
member.summary: An array of 32-bit unsigned integers representing attribute bitmaps. Each bit position corresponds to a specific NFSv4 file attribute (e.g., size, mode, owner). The bitmap can extend across multiple words to support all defined attributes. Bit 0 of Value[0] is the lowest attribute, bit 31 of Value[0] is attribute 31, bit 0 of Value[1] is attribute 32, and so on.

member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class.

member.name: T:NFSLibrary.Protocols.V4.RPC.Fattr4
member.summary: Represents file attributes for NFSv4 operations.

member.name: F:NFSLibrary.Protocols.V4.RPC.Fattr4.Attrmask
member.summary: A bitmap indicating which attributes are present in the attr_vals field. Each bit position corresponds to a specific NFSv4 attribute. Only attributes with their corresponding bit set in this mask are included in attr_vals.

member.name: F:NFSLibrary.Protocols.V4.RPC.Fattr4.Attr_vals
member.summary: The encoded attribute values corresponding to the bits set in attrmask. This is a packed, opaque representation of the requested attributes in the order specified by the NFSv4 protocol (ordered by attribute number).

member.name: T:NFSLibrary.Protocols.V4.RPC.NFSv4ProtocolClient

member.name: T:NFSLibrary.Protocols.V4.RPC.Sequenceid4
member.summary: Represents a sequence identifier in NFSv4 protocol.

member.name: F:NFSLibrary.Protocols.V4.RPC.Sequenceid4.Value
member.summary: A monotonically increasing 32-bit unsigned integer used to order operations and detect duplicate or out-of-order requests. Different contexts use sequence IDs for different purposes: lock owners use them to sequence lock operations, open owners use them for open operations, and NFSv4.1 sessions use them in the SEQUENCE operation.

member.summary: Encodes this Sequenceid4 instance to the specified XDR stream.

member.summary: Represents a session ID in NFSv4 protocol.

member.name: F:NFSLibrary.Protocols.V4.RPC.Sessionid4.Value
member.summary: The opaque session identifier used in NFSv4.1 and later to identify a client-server session. This is a fixed-size array (NFS4_SESSIONID_SIZE bytes) that uniquely identifies the session established via CREATE_SESSION and used for SEQUENCE operations.

member.name: T:NFSLibrary.Protocols.V4.RPC.Stubs.AcessStub
member.summary: Provides stub methods for creating NFSv4 ACCESS operation requests. The ACCESS operation checks the access permissions for the current file handle, allowing clients to verify whether they have specific types of access (read, write, execute) before attempting file operations.

member.name: M:NFSLibrary.Protocols.V4.RPC.Stubs.AcessStub.GenerateRequest(NFSLibrary.Protocols.V4.RPC.Uint32T)
member.summary: Generates an ACCESS operation request with the specified access arguments.
member.param: The access arguments specifying the access mode.
member.returns: An NfsArgop4 structure containing the ACCESS operation request.

member.name: T:NFSLibrary.Protocols.V4.RPC.Stubs.CloseStub
member.summary: Provides stub methods for creating NFSv4 CLOSE operation requests. The CLOSE operation releases the state associated with an open file, releasing locks and other state information maintained by the server for that open file handle. This should be called when a client is done with a file opened via the OPEN operation.

member.name: M:NFSLibrary.Protocols.V4.RPC.Stubs.CloseStub.GenerateRequest(NFSLibrary.Protocols.V4.RPC.Stateid4)
member.summary: Generates a CLOSE operation request to close an open file.
member.param: The state ID of the open file to close.
member.returns: An NfsArgop4 structure containing the CLOSE operation request.

member.name: T:NFSLibrary.Protocols.V4.RPC.Stubs.CreateSessionStub
member.summary: Provides stub methods for creating NFSv4.1 CREATE_SESSION operation requests. The CREATE_SESSION operation establishes a session between the client and server, which is required for NFSv4.1 operations. Sessions provide connection association, exactly-once semantics, and support for callbacks. This must be called after EXCHANGE_ID and before performing file operations in NFSv4.1.

member.name: M:NFSLibrary.Protocols.V4.RPC.Stubs.CreateSessionStub.Standard(NFSLibrary.Protocols.V4.RPC.Clientid4,NFSLibrary.Protocols.V4.RPC.Sequenceid4)
member.summary: Generates a standard CREATE_SESSION operation request for establishing a session. Configures both fore channel (client-to-server) and back channel (server-to-client) attributes with reasonable defaults for typical NFS operations.
member.param: The client ID obtained from EXCHANGE_ID response.
The sequence ID obtained from EXCHANGE_ID response.
member.returns: An NfsArgop4 structure containing the CREATE_SESSION operation request.

member.name: T:NFSLibrary.Protocols.V4.RPC.Stubs.CreateStub
member.summary: Provides stub methods for creating NFSv4 CREATE operation requests. The CREATE operation creates a new non-regular file object (directory, named pipe, etc.) in the current directory. This implementation specifically creates directories. For regular files, use the OPEN operation instead.

member.name: M:NFSLibrary.Protocols.V4.RPC.Stubs.CreateStub.GenerateRequest(System.String,NFSLibrary.Protocols.V4.RPC.Fattr4)
member.summary: Generates a CREATE operation request to create a new directory.
member.param: The name of the directory to create.
The file attributes for the new directory.
member.returns: An NfsArgop4 structure containing the CREATE operation request.

member.name: T:NFSLibrary.Protocols.V4.RPC.Stubs.DestroyClientIdStub
member.summary: Provides stub methods for creating NFSv4.1 DESTROY_CLIENTID operation requests. The DESTROY_CLIENTID operation destroys a client ID that was created via EXCHANGE_ID, releasing all state associated with that client. This should only be called when the client has no active sessions or state on the server.

member.name: M:NFSLibrary.Protocols.V4.RPC.Stubs.DestroyClientIdStub.Standard(NFSLibrary.Protocols.V4.RPC.Clientid4)
member.summary: Generates a standard DESTROY_CLIENTID operation request to destroy a client ID.
member.returns: An NfsArgop4 structure containing the DESTROY_CLIENTID operation request.

member.name: T:NFSLibrary.Protocols.V4.RPC.Stubs.DestroySessionStub
member.summary: Provides stub methods for creating NFSv4.1 DESTROY_SESSION operation requests. The DESTROY_SESSION operation terminates a session previously created with CREATE_SESSION, releasing all resources and state associated with that session. This should be called when disconnecting from the server or when the session is no longer needed.

member.name: M:NFSLibrary.Protocols.V4.RPC.Stubs.DestroySessionStub.Standard(NFSLibrary.Protocols.V4.RPC.Sessionid4)
member.summary: Generates a standard DESTROY_SESSION operation request to terminate a session.
member.returns: An NfsArgop4 structure containing the DESTROY_SESSION operation request.

member.name: T:NFSLibrary.Protocols.V4.RPC.Stubs.ExchengeIDStub
member.summary: Provides stub methods for creating NFSv4.1 EXCHANGE_ID operation requests. The EXCHANGE_ID operation establishes a client ID on the server, which is the first step in establishing NFSv4.1 session semantics. It exchanges client and server implementation information and creates a client identifier that will be used in subsequent CREATE_SESSION operations.

member.name: M:NFSLibrary.Protocols.V4.RPC.Stubs.ExchengeIDStub.Normal(System.String,System.String,System.String,System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Generates a normal EXCHANGE_ID operation request for client identification. This creates a client identifier using the current machine name and timestamp-based verifier to ensure uniqueness across client restarts.
member.param: The implementation domain name (e.g., organization domain).
The implementation name (e.g., application or library name).
The client owner ID (unique identifier for this client instance).
The exchange ID flags controlling session behavior.
The state protection mode (e.g., AUTH_SYS, RPCSEC_GSS).
member.returns: An NfsArgop4 structure containing the EXCHANGE_ID operation request.

member.name: T:NFSLibrary.Protocols.V4.RPC.Stubs.GetattrStub
member.summary: Provides stub methods for creating NFSv4 GETATTR operation requests and decoding attribute responses. The GETATTR operation retrieves file or directory attributes (metadata) such as size, mode, type, and timestamps. Attributes are requested using a bitmap mask and returned in encoded XDR format. This class handles both building requests and decoding the attribute responses.

member.name: M:NFSLibrary.Protocols.V4.RPC.Stubs.GetattrStub.GenerateRequest(System.Collections.Generic.List{System.Int32})
member.summary: Generates a GETATTR operation request to retrieve file attributes. The attribute IDs are converted into a bitmap mask that tells the server which attributes to return in the response.
member.param: List of attribute IDs to retrieve (e.g., FATTR4_SIZE, FATTR4_MODE).
member.returns: An NfsArgop4 structure containing the GETATTR operation request.

member.name: M:NFSLibrary.Protocols.V4.RPC.Stubs.GetattrStub.DecodeType(NFSLibrary.Protocols.V4.RPC.Fattr4)
member.summary: Decodes file attributes from an Fattr4 structure. Extracts the attribute bitmap to determine which attributes are present, then decodes each attribute from the XDR-encoded byte stream.
member.param: The Fattr4 structure containing encoded attributes from the server response.
member.returns: A dictionary mapping attribute IDs to their decoded values (typed objects like uint64_t, mode4, Nfstime4).

member.name: M:NFSLibrary.Protocols.V4.RPC.Stubs.GetattrStub.xdr2fattr(System.Collections.Generic.Dictionary{System.Int32,System.Object},System.Int32,NFSLibrary.Rpc.XdrDecodingStream)
member.summary: Decodes a specific attribute from XDR stream and adds it to the attribute dictionary. Currently supports decoding SIZE, MODE, TYPE, and various time attributes. Unsupported attributes are silently skipped.
member.param: The dictionary to add the decoded attribute to.
The attribute ID to decode (e.g., FATTR4_SIZE, FATTR4_MODE).
The XDR decoding stream positioned at the attribute value.

member.name: T:NFSLibrary.Protocols.V4.RPC.Stubs.GetfhStub
member.summary: Provides stub methods for creating NFSv4 GETFH operation requests. The GETFH operation retrieves the current file handle after a LOOKUP or other operation that changes the current file handle context. File handles are used to identify files and directories in subsequent operations like READ, WRITE, and GETATTR.

member.name: M:NFSLibrary.Protocols.V4.RPC.Stubs.GetfhStub.GenerateRequest
member.summary: Generates a GETFH operation request to retrieve the current file handle.
member.returns: An NfsArgop4 structure containing the GETFH operation request.

member.name: T:NFSLibrary.Protocols.V4.RPC.Stubs.LinkStub
member.summary: Provides stub methods for creating NFSv4 LINK operation requests. The LINK operation creates a hard link from the saved file handle (set via SAVEFH) to a new name in the current directory (set via PUTFH).

member.name: M:NFSLibrary.Protocols.V4.RPC.Stubs.LinkStub.GenerateRequest(System.String)
member.summary: Generates a LINK operation request to create a hard link.
member.param: The name for the new hard link in the current directory.
member.returns: An NfsArgop4 structure containing the LINK operation request.
member.remarks: Before calling LINK, the compound must include: 1. PUTFH to set the source file as current file handle 2. SAVEFH to save the source file handle 3. PUTFH to set the destination directory as current file handle 4. LINK with the new name

member.name: T:NFSLibrary.Protocols.V4.RPC.Stubs.LookupStub
member.summary: Provides stub methods for creating NFSv4 LOOKUP operation requests. The LOOKUP operation traverses one component of a pathname, changing the current file handle to the named object within the current directory. Multiple LOOKUP operations are typically chained together to resolve full pathnames.

member.name: M:NFSLibrary.Protocols.V4.RPC.Stubs.LookupStub.GenerateRequest(System.String)
member.summary: Generates a LOOKUP operation request to resolve a path component. This should be a single path component (directory or file name), not a full path.
member.param: The path component to look up (e.g., "mydir" or "file.txt").
member.returns: An NfsArgop4 structure containing the LOOKUP operation request.

member.name: T:NFSLibrary.Protocols.V4.RPC.Stubs.OpenStub
member.summary: Provides stub methods for creating NFSv4 OPEN operation requests. The OPEN operation establishes access to a regular file, creating it if requested. It returns a stateid that must be used in subsequent READ, WRITE, and CLOSE operations. This class provides methods for different open scenarios: reading existing files, creating new files, and opening files without creation.

member.name: M:NFSLibrary.Protocols.V4.RPC.Stubs.OpenStub.NormalREAD(System.String,System.Int32,NFSLibrary.Protocols.V4.RPC.Clientid4,System.Int32)
member.summary: Generates an OPEN operation request for read access to an existing file. This operation will fail if the file does not exist (OPEN4_NOCREATE).
member.param: The name of the file to open in the current directory.
The sequence ID for the operation.
The client ID obtained from EXCHANGE_ID.
The access mode flags (parameter is present but overridden to READ).
member.returns: An NfsArgop4 structure containing the OPEN operation request.

member.name: M:NFSLibrary.Protocols.V4.RPC.Stubs.OpenStub.NormalCREATE(System.String,System.Int32,NFSLibrary.Protocols.V4.RPC.Clientid4,System.Int32)
member.summary: Generates an OPEN operation request to create a new file. Uses GUARDED4 mode to ensure the file doesn't already exist. Creates the file with default attributes (mode 0777).
member.param: The name of the file to create in the current directory.
The sequence ID for the operation.
The client ID obtained from EXCHANGE_ID.
member.returns: An NfsArgop4 structure containing the OPEN operation request.

member.name: M:NFSLibrary.Protocols.V4.RPC.Stubs.OpenStub.NormalOPENonly(System.String,System.Int32,NFSLibrary.Protocols.V4.RPC.Clientid4,System.Int32)
member.summary: Generates an OPEN operation request for opening an existing file without creating it. Similar to normalREAD but allows specifying custom access flags. Uses OPEN4_NOCREATE to ensure the file must already exist.
member.param: The name of the file to open in the current directory.
The sequence ID for the operation.
The client ID obtained from EXCHANGE_ID.
The access mode flags (e.g., OPEN4_SHARE_ACCESS_READ or WRITE).
member.returns: An NfsArgop4 structure containing the OPEN operation request.

member.name: M:NFSLibrary.Protocols.V4.RPC.Stubs.OpenStub.OpenFattrBitmap
member.summary: Creates a Bitmap4 structure with attribute masks for file open operations. Configures the bitmap to include SIZE and MODE attributes, which are commonly set when creating or opening files.
member.returns: A Bitmap4 structure configured for SIZE and MODE attributes.

member.name: M:NFSLibrary.Protocols.V4.RPC.Stubs.OpenStub.OpenAttrs(System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int64)
member.summary: Encodes file attributes (mode and size) into a byte array for OPEN operations. Note: The permission parameters are currently ignored and overridden to 0777 (rwxrwxrwx). Encodes attributes in XDR format as required by the NFSv4 protocol.
member.param: User permission bits (0-7) - currently ignored, defaults to 7.
Group permission bits (0-7) - currently ignored, defaults to 7.
Other permission bits (0-7) - currently ignored, defaults to 7.
The file size to set (typically 0 for new files).
member.returns: A byte array containing the XDR-encoded attributes.

member.name: T:NFSLibrary.Protocols.V4.RPC.Stubs.PutfhStub
member.summary: Provides stub methods for creating NFSv4 PUTFH operation requests. The PUTFH operation sets the current file handle to a previously obtained file handle, allowing subsequent operations to work on that file or directory. This is commonly used to restore a saved file handle context when navigating the filesystem.

member.name: M:NFSLibrary.Protocols.V4.RPC.Stubs.PutfhStub.GenerateRequest(NFSLibrary.Protocols.V4.RPC.NfsFh4)
member.summary: Generates a PUTFH operation request to set the current file handle.
member.param: The file handle to set as current.
member.returns: An NfsArgop4 structure containing the PUTFH operation request.

member.name: T:NFSLibrary.Protocols.V4.RPC.Stubs.PutrootfhStub
member.summary: Provides stub methods for creating NFSv4 PUTROOTFH operation requests. The PUTROOTFH operation sets the current file handle to the root of the filesystem pseudo-tree on the server. This is typically the first operation in a compound request when beginning to navigate the filesystem from the root.

member.name: M:NFSLibrary.Protocols.V4.RPC.Stubs.PutrootfhStub.GenerateRequest
member.summary: Generates a PUTROOTFH operation request to set the current file handle to the root.
member.returns: An NfsArgop4 structure containing the PUTROOTFH operation request.

member.name: T:NFSLibrary.Protocols.V4.RPC.Stubs.ReadDirStub
member.summary: Provides stub methods for creating NFSv4 READDIR operation requests. The READDIR operation reads directory entries from the current directory file handle. It supports pagination using cookies and verifiers to handle large directories that cannot be returned in a single response.

member.name: M:NFSLibrary.Protocols.V4.RPC.Stubs.ReadDirStub.GenerateRequest(System.Int64,NFSLibrary.Protocols.V4.RPC.Verifier4)
member.summary: Generates a READDIR operation request to read directory entries. Uses a cookie of 0 to start from the beginning, or a previous cookie to continue. Configured to retrieve up to 10000 bytes of directory entries.
member.param: The cookie for resuming directory reads (0 to start from beginning).
The cookie verifier to validate directory hasn't changed between calls.
member.returns: An NfsArgop4 structure containing the READDIR operation request.

member.name: T:NFSLibrary.Protocols.V4.RPC.Stubs.ReadLinkStub
member.summary: Provides stub methods for creating NFSv4 READLINK operation requests. The READLINK operation reads the contents of a symbolic link.

member.name: M:NFSLibrary.Protocols.V4.RPC.Stubs.ReadLinkStub.GenerateRequest
member.summary: Generates a READLINK operation request.
member.returns: An NfsArgop4 structure containing the READLINK operation request.
member.remarks: READLINK takes no arguments; it operates on the current file handle which must be set to a symbolic link via PUTFH before calling READLINK.

member.name: T:NFSLibrary.Protocols.V4.RPC.Stubs.ReadStub
member.summary: Provides stub methods for creating NFSv4 READ operation requests. The READ operation reads data from a regular file that has been opened with the OPEN operation. It requires a valid stateid obtained from the OPEN operation and supports reading data at specific offsets in the file.

member.name: M:NFSLibrary.Protocols.V4.RPC.Stubs.ReadStub.GenerateRequest(System.Int32,System.Int64,NFSLibrary.Protocols.V4.RPC.Stateid4)
member.summary: Generates a READ operation request to read data from a file.
member.param: The number of bytes to read.
The offset in the file to start reading from.
The state ID of the open file.
member.returns: An NfsArgop4 structure containing the READ operation request.

member.name: T:NFSLibrary.Protocols.V4.RPC.Stubs.ReclaimCompleteStub
member.summary: Provides stub methods for creating NFSv4.1 RECLAIM_COMPLETE operation requests. The RECLAIM_COMPLETE operation indicates that the client has finished reclaiming state after a server restart or network partition. This is required in NFSv4.1 before the client can perform non-reclaim operations. It should be sent once per client ID after CREATE_SESSION.

member.name: M:NFSLibrary.Protocols.V4.RPC.Stubs.ReclaimCompleteStub.GenerateRequest(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Generates a RECLAIM_COMPLETE operation request to indicate completion of state reclaim. Typically called with false to indicate all filesystems are complete.
member.param: If true, reclaim is complete for one filesystem; if false, for all filesystems.
member.returns: An NfsArgop4 structure containing the RECLAIM_COMPLETE operation request.

member.name: T:NFSLibrary.Protocols.V4.RPC.Stubs.RemoveStub
member.summary: Provides stub methods for creating NFSv4 REMOVE operation requests. The REMOVE operation deletes a file or directory from the current directory. For directories, the directory must be empty. The current file handle must refer to the parent directory containing the object to be removed.

member.name: M:NFSLibrary.Protocols.V4.RPC.Stubs.RemoveStub.GenerateRequest(System.String)
member.summary: Generates a REMOVE operation request to delete a file or directory.
member.param: The path of the file or directory to remove.
member.returns: An NfsArgop4 structure containing the REMOVE operation request.

member.name: T:NFSLibrary.Protocols.V4.RPC.Stubs.RenameStub
member.summary: Provides stub methods for creating NFSv4 RENAME operation requests. The RENAME operation renames a file or directory from the old name to the new name. Both names are relative to the saved directory (set via SAVEFH) for the source and the current directory for the destination. Typically used in a compound with SAVEFH and PUTFH operations to handle cross-directory renames.

member.name: M:NFSLibrary.Protocols.V4.RPC.Stubs.RenameStub.GenerateRequest(System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Generates a RENAME operation request to rename a file or directory.
member.param: The current name of the file or directory.
The new name for the file or directory.
member.returns: An NfsArgop4 structure containing the RENAME operation request.

member.name: T:NFSLibrary.Protocols.V4.RPC.Stubs.SavefhStub
member.summary: Provides stub methods for creating NFSv4 SAVEFH operation requests. The SAVEFH operation saves the current file handle to a saved file handle slot, which can later be restored using RESTOREFH. This is useful for operations that need to work with two file handles simultaneously (e.g., RENAME, LINK).

member.name: M:NFSLibrary.Protocols.V4.RPC.Stubs.SavefhStub.GenerateRequest
member.summary: Generates a SAVEFH operation request to save the current file handle.
member.returns: An NfsArgop4 structure containing the SAVEFH operation request.

member.name: T:NFSLibrary.Protocols.V4.RPC.Stubs.SequenceStub
member.summary: Provides stub methods for creating NFSv4.1 SEQUENCE operation requests. The SEQUENCE operation provides session semantics, exactly-once execution guarantees, and request ordering in NFSv4.1. It must be the first operation in every compound request when using sessions. It manages sequence IDs, slot IDs, and caching to prevent duplicate request execution.

member.name: M:NFSLibrary.Protocols.V4.RPC.Stubs.SequenceStub.GenerateRequest(System.Boolean,System.Byte[],System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Generates a SEQUENCE operation request for session management. Note: This method increments the SeqId parameter, so the caller should pass the current sequence ID, not the next one.
member.param: If true, server should cache this request for replay detection.
The session ID obtained from CREATE_SESSION.
The current sequence ID (will be incremented by this method).
The highest slot ID in use by the client.
The slot ID for this request (usually 0 for single-threaded clients).
member.returns: An NfsArgop4 structure containing the SEQUENCE operation request.

member.name: T:NFSLibrary.Protocols.V4.RPC.Stubs.SetAttrStub
member.summary: Provides stub methods for creating NFSv4 SETATTR operation requests. The SETATTR operation changes file or directory attributes (metadata) such as size, mode, owner, and timestamps. This implementation currently supports setting the file size, which is commonly used for truncating or extending files. Requires a valid stateid from an OPEN operation when modifying certain attributes.

member.name: M:NFSLibrary.Protocols.V4.RPC.Stubs.SetAttrStub.GenerateSetSizeRequest(NFSLibrary.Protocols.V4.RPC.Stateid4,System.Int64)
member.summary: Generates a SETATTR operation request to set the file size. This is commonly used to truncate a file to a smaller size or extend it to a larger size. Requires the file to be opened with appropriate access rights.
member.param: The state ID of the open file obtained from OPEN operation.
The new size for the file in bytes (can be larger or smaller than current size).
member.returns: An NfsArgop4 structure containing the SETATTR operation request.

member.name: M:NFSLibrary.Protocols.V4.RPC.Stubs.SetAttrStub.sizeFattrBitmap
member.summary: Creates a Bitmap4 structure with the SIZE attribute mask. The bitmap tells the server which attributes are being set in this operation.
member.returns: A Bitmap4 structure configured for the SIZE attribute (Fattr4Size).

member.name: M:NFSLibrary.Protocols.V4.RPC.Stubs.SetAttrStub.encodeSizeAttr(System.Int64)
member.summary: Encodes a size attribute value into a byte array. Uses XDR encoding as required by the NFSv4 protocol for attribute values.
member.param: The size value to encode in bytes.
member.returns: A byte array containing the XDR-encoded size attribute.

member.name: T:NFSLibrary.Protocols.V4.RPC.Stubs.SymlinkStub
member.summary: Provides stub methods for creating NFSv4 symbolic link creation requests. Uses the CREATE operation with NF4LNK file type to create symbolic links.

member.name: M:NFSLibrary.Protocols.V4.RPC.Stubs.SymlinkStub.GenerateRequest(System.String,System.String,NFSLibrary.Protocols.V4.RPC.Fattr4)
member.summary: Generates a CREATE operation request to create a symbolic link.
member.param: The name of the symbolic link to create.
The target path the symbolic link will point to.
The file attributes for the symbolic link.
member.returns: An NfsArgop4 structure containing the CREATE operation request.

member.name: T:NFSLibrary.Protocols.V4.RPC.Stubs.WriteStub
member.summary: Provides stub methods for creating NFSv4 WRITE operation requests. The WRITE operation writes data to a regular file that has been opened with the OPEN operation. It requires a valid stateid obtained from the OPEN operation and supports writing data at specific offsets in the file. This implementation uses UNSTABLE4 mode for better performance, which allows the server to cache writes before committing them to stable storage.

member.name: M:NFSLibrary.Protocols.V4.RPC.Stubs.WriteStub.GenerateRequest(System.Int64,System.Byte[],NFSLibrary.Protocols.V4.RPC.Stateid4)
member.summary: Generates a WRITE operation request to write data to a file. Uses UNSTABLE4 mode by default, which allows server-side caching for better performance. For guaranteed synchronous writes, change the stable mode to FILE_SYNC4.
member.param: The offset in the file to start writing at (in bytes).
The data to write to the file.
The state ID of the open file obtained from OPEN operation.
member.returns: An NfsArgop4 structure containing the WRITE operation request.

member.name: T:NFSLibrary.Protocols.V4.RPC.Verifier4
member.summary: Represents a verifier value in NFSv4 protocol.

member.name: F:NFSLibrary.Protocols.V4.RPC.Verifier4.Value
member.summary: A 64-bit opaque value used to verify various NFSv4 operations. Commonly used in exclusive file creation to ensure idempotency, in COMMIT operations to verify server reboots, and in SETCLIENTID to distinguish different client instances. The server typically uses a boot time or similar value that changes on restart.

member.name: T:NFSLibrary.Rpc.OncRpcAcceptStatus
member.summary: A collection of constants used to identify the acceptance status of ONC/RPC reply messages.
member.remarks: A collection of constants used to identify the acceptance status of ONC/RPC reply messages. Converted to C# using the db4o Sharpen tool.
member.author: Harald Albrecht
Jay Walters

member.name: F:NFSLibrary.Rpc.OncRpcAcceptStatus.ONCRPC_SUCCESS
member.summary: The remote procedure was called and executed successfully.
member.remarks: The remote procedure was called and executed successfully.

member.name: F:NFSLibrary.Rpc.OncRpcAcceptStatus.ONCRPC_PROG_UNAVAIL
member.summary: The program requested is not available.
member.remarks: The program requested is not available. So the remote host does not export this particular program and the ONC/RPC server which you tried to send a RPC call message doesn't know of this program either.

member.name: F:NFSLibrary.Rpc.OncRpcAcceptStatus.ONCRPC_PROG_MISMATCH
member.summary: A program version number mismatch occured.
member.remarks: A program version number mismatch occured. The remote ONC/RPC server does not support this particular version of the program.

member.name: F:NFSLibrary.Rpc.OncRpcAcceptStatus.ONCRPC_PROC_UNAVAIL
member.summary: The procedure requested is not available.
member.remarks: The procedure requested is not available. The remote ONC/RPC server does not support this particular procedure.

member.name: F:NFSLibrary.Rpc.OncRpcAcceptStatus.ONCRPC_GARBAGE_ARGS
member.summary: The server could not decode the arguments sent within the ONC/RPC call message.
member.remarks: The server could not decode the arguments sent within the ONC/RPC call message.

member.name: F:NFSLibrary.Rpc.OncRpcAcceptStatus.ONCRPC_SYSTEM_ERR
member.summary: The server encountered a system error and thus was not able to process the procedure call.
member.remarks: The server encountered a system error and thus was not able to process the procedure call. Causes might be memory shortage, desinterest and sloth.

member.name: T:NFSLibrary.Rpc.OncRpcAuthType
member.summary: A collection of constants used to identify the authentication schemes available for ONC/RPC.
member.remarks: A collection of constants used to identify the authentication schemes available for ONC/RPC. Please note that currently only ONCRPC_AUTH_NONE is supported by this Java package. Converted to C# using the db4o Sharpen tool.
member.author: Harald Albrecht
Jay Walters

member.name: F:NFSLibrary.Rpc.OncRpcAuthType.ONCRPC_AUTH_NONE
member.summary: No authentication scheme used for this remote procedure call.
member.remarks: No authentication scheme used for this remote procedure call.

member.name: F:NFSLibrary.Rpc.OncRpcAuthType.ONCRPC_AUTH_UNIX
member.summary: The so-called "Unix" authentication scheme is not supported.
member.remarks: The so-called "Unix" authentication scheme is not supported. This one only sends the users id as well as her/his group identifiers, so this is simply far too weak to use in typical situations where authentication is requested.

member.summary: The so-called "short hand Unix style" is not supported.
member.remarks: The so-called "short hand Unix style" is not supported.

member.name: F:NFSLibrary.Rpc.OncRpcAuthType.ONCRPC_AUTH_DES
member.summary: The DES authentication scheme (using encrypted time stamps) is not supported -- and besides, it's not a silver bullet either.
member.remarks: The DES authentication scheme (using encrypted time stamps) is not supported -- and besides, it's not a silver bullet either.

member.name: T:NFSLibrary.Rpc.OncRpcBroadcastListener
member.summary: The listener class for receiving ONC/RPC broadcast reply events . Converted to C# using the db4o Sharpen tool.
member.author: Harald Albrecht
Jay Walters

member.name: M:NFSLibrary.Rpc.OncRpcBroadcastListener.replyReceived(NFSLibrary.Rpc.OncRpcBroadcastEvent)
member.summary: Invoked when a reply to an ONC/RPC broadcast call is received.
member.remarks:
Invoked when a reply to an ONC/RPC broadcast call is received.
Please note that you should not spend too much time when handling broadcast events, otherwise you'll probably miss some of the incomming replies. Because most operating systems will not buffer large amount of incomming UDP/IP datagramms for a given socket, you will experience packet drops when you stay too long in the processing stage.
member.param: The broadcast event containing the reply information.

member.name: T:NFSLibrary.Rpc.OncRpcCallMessage
member.summary: The OncRpcCallMessage class represents a remote procedure call message as defined by ONC/RPC in RFC 1831.
member.remarks:
The OncRpcCallMessage class represents a remote procedure call message as defined by ONC/RPC in RFC 1831. Such messages are sent by ONC/RPC clients to servers in order to request a remote procedure call.
Note that this is an abstract class. Because call message objects also need to deal with authentication protocol issues, they need help of so-called authentication protocol handling objects. These objects are of different classes, depending on where they are used (either within the server or the client).
Please also note that this class implements no encoding or decoding functionality: it doesn't need them. Only derived classes will be able to be encoded on the side of the client and decoded at the end of the server. Converted to C# using the db4o Sharpen tool.
member.author: Harald Albrecht
Jay Walters

member.name: F:NFSLibrary.Rpc.OncRpcCallMessage.ONCRPC_VERSION
member.summary: Protocol version used by this ONC/RPC Java implementation.
member.remarks: Protocol version used by this ONC/RPC Java implementation. The protocol version 2 is defined in RFC 1831.

member.summary: Protocol version used by this ONC/RPC call message.
member.remarks: Protocol version used by this ONC/RPC call message.

member.remarks: Program number of this particular remote procedure call message.

member.name: M:NFSLibrary.Rpc.OncRpcClient.call(System.Int32,NFSLibrary.Rpc.XdrAble,NFSLibrary.Rpc.XdrAble)
member.summary: Calls a remote procedure on an ONC/RPC server.
member.remarks:
Calls a remote procedure on an ONC/RPC server.
The OncRpcUdpClient uses a similar timeout scheme as the genuine Sun C implementation of ONC/RPC: it starts with a timeout of one second when waiting for a reply. If no reply is received within this time frame, the client doubles the timeout, sends a new request and then waits again for a reply. In every case the client will wait no longer than the total timeout set through the SetTimeout(int) method.
member.param: Procedure number of the procedure to call.
The parameters of the procedure to call, contained in an object which implements the XdrAble interface.
The object receiving the result of the procedure call.

member.name: M:NFSLibrary.Rpc.OncRpcClient.call(System.Int32,System.Int32,NFSLibrary.Rpc.XdrAble,NFSLibrary.Rpc.XdrAble)
member.summary: Calls a remote procedure on an ONC/RPC server.
member.remarks: Calls a remote procedure on an ONC/RPC server.
member.param: Procedure number of the procedure to call.
The parameters of the procedure to call, contained in an object which implements the XdrAble interface.
The object receiving the result of the procedure call.

member.name: M:NFSLibrary.Rpc.OncRpcClient.SetTimeout(System.Int32)
member.summary: Set the timout for remote procedure calls to wait for an answer from the ONC/RPC server.
member.remarks: Set the timout for remote procedure calls to wait for an answer from the ONC/RPC server. If the timeout expires, call(int, XdrAble, XdrAble) will raise an exception. The default timeout value is 30 seconds (30,000 milliseconds). The timeout must be > 0. A timeout of zero indicated batched calls, for which no reply message is expected.
member.param: Timeout in milliseconds. A timeout of zero indicates batched calls.

member.summary: Retrieve the current timeout set for remote procedure calls.
member.remarks: Retrieve the current timeout set for remote procedure calls. A timeout of zero indicates batching calls (no reply message is expected).
member.returns: Current timeout.

member.name: T:NFSLibrary.Rpc.OncRpcClientAuth
member.summary: The OncRpcClientAuth class is the base class for handling all protocol issues of ONC/RPC authentication on the client side.
member.remarks:
The OncRpcClientAuth class is the base class for handling all protocol issues of ONC/RPC authentication on the client side. As it stands, it does not do very much with the exception of defining the contract for the behaviour of derived classes with respect to protocol handling issues.
Authentication on the client side can be done as follows: just create an authentication object and hand it over to the ONC/RPC client object.
OncRpcClientAuth auth = new OncRpcClientAuthUnix( "marvin@ford.prefect", 42, 1001, new int[0]); client.setAuth(auth);
The authentication AUTH_UNIX will handle shorthand credentials (of type AUTH_SHORT transparently). If you do not set any authentication object after creating an ONC/RPC client object, AUTH_NONE is used automatically. Converted to C# using the db4o Sharpen tool.
member.author: Harald Albrecht
Jay Walters

member.name: T:NFSLibrary.Rpc.OncRpcClientReplyMessage
member.summary: The OncRpcReplyMessage class represents an ONC/RPC reply message as defined by ONC/RPC in RFC 1831.
member.remarks:
The OncRpcReplyMessage class represents an ONC/RPC reply message as defined by ONC/RPC in RFC 1831. Such messages are sent back by ONC/RPC to servers to clients and contain (in case of real success) the result of a remote procedure call.
The decision to define only one single class for the accepted and rejected replies was driven by the motivation not to use polymorphism and thus have to upcast and downcast references all the time.
The derived classes are only provided for convinience on the server side.
Converted to C# using the db4o Sharpen tool.
member.author: Harald Albrecht
Jay Walters

member.param: Client-side authentication protocol handling object which is to be used when decoding the verifier data contained in the reply.

member.name: T:NFSLibrary.Rpc.OncRpcClientStub
member.summary: The abstract OncRpcClientStub class is the base class to build ONC/RPC-program specific clients upon.
member.remarks:
The abstract OncRpcClientStub class is the base class to build ONC/RPC-program specific clients upon. This class is typically only used by jrpcgen generated clients, which provide a particular set of remote procedures as defined in a x-file.
When you do not need the client proxy object any longer, you should return the resources it occupies to the system. Use the Close() method for this.
client.close(); client = null; // Hint to the garbage (wo)man
Converted to C# using the db4o Sharpen tool.
member.author: Harald Albrecht
Jay Walters

member.name: T:NFSLibrary.Rpc.OncRpcException
member.summary: The class OncRpcException indicates ONC/RPC conditions that a reasonable application might want to catch.
member.remarks:
The class OncRpcException indicates ONC/RPC conditions that a reasonable application might want to catch. We follow here the notation established by the Java environment that exceptions can be caught while errors usually can't. Because we don't want to throw our applications out of the virtual machine (should I mock here "out of the window"?), we only define exceptions.
The class OncRpcException also defines a set of ONC/RPC error codes as defined by RFC 1831. Note that all these error codes are solely used on the client-side or server-side, but never transmitted over the wire. For error codes transmitted over the network, refer to OncRpcAcceptStatus and OncRpcRejectStatus . System.Exception Converted to C# using the db4o Sharpen tool.
member.author: Harald Albrecht
Jay Walters

member.name: T:NFSLibrary.Rpc.OncRpcMessage
member.summary: The OncRpcMessage class is an abstract superclass for all the message types ONC/RPC defines (well, an overwhelming count of two).
member.remarks: The OncRpcMessage class is an abstract superclass for all the message types ONC/RPC defines (well, an overwhelming count of two). The only things common to all ONC/RPC messages are a message identifier and the message type. All other things do not come in until derived classes are introduced. Converted to C# using the db4o Sharpen tool.

member.remarks: The message id is used to identify matching ONC/RPC calls and replies. This is typically choosen by the communication partner sending a request. The matching reply then must have the same message identifier, so the receiver can match calls and replies.

member.name: T:NFSLibrary.Rpc.OncRpcMessageType
member.summary: A collection of constants used for ONC/RPC messages to identify the type of message.
member.remarks: A collection of constants used for ONC/RPC messages to identify the type of message. Currently, ONC/RPC messages can be either calls or replies. Calls are sent by ONC/RPC clients to servers to call a remote procedure (for you "ohohpies" that can be translated into the buzzword "method"). A server then will answer with a corresponding reply message (but not in the case of batched calls). Converted to C# using the db4o Sharpen tool.

member.name: F:NFSLibrary.Rpc.OncRpcMessageType.ONCRPC_REPLY
member.summary: Identifies an ONC/RPC reply.
member.remarks: Identifies an ONC/RPC reply. A server responds with a "reply" after a client has sent a "call" for a particular remote procedure, sending back the results of calling that procedure.

member.name: T:NFSLibrary.Rpc.OncRpcPortmapClient
member.summary: The class OncRpcPortmapClient is a specialized ONC/RPC client, which can talk to the portmapper on a given host using the famous UDP/IP datagram-oriented internet protocol.
member.remarks:
The class OncRpcPortmapClient is a specialized ONC/RPC client, which can talk to the portmapper on a given host using the famous UDP/IP datagram-oriented internet protocol. In addition, it is also possible to contact portmappers using TCP/IP. For this, the constructor of the OncRpcPortmapClient class also accepts a protocol parameter ( OncRpcPortmapClient(IPAddress, int)
). Technically spoken, instances of OncRpcPortmapClient are proxy objects. OncRpcPortmapClient objects currently speak protocol version 2. The newer transport-independent protocol versions 3 and 4 are not supported as the transport-independent ONC/RPC implementation is not that widely in use due to the brain-damaged design of XTI. If you should ever have programmed using XTI (transport independent interface) then you'll know what I mean and probably agree with me. Otherwise, in case you find XTI the best thing since the Win32 API, please implement the rpcbind protocol versions 3 and 4 and give it to the community -- thank you.
Here are some simple examples of how to use the portmapper proxy object. We first start with one of the most interesting operations, which can be performed on portmappers, querying the port of a local or remote ONC/RPC server.
To query the port number of an ONC/RPC server, we need to contact the portmapper at the host machine where the server is running. The following code snippet just contacts the local portmapper. try blocks are ommited for brevity -- but remember that you almost allways need to catch OncRpcException as well as IOException.
OncRpcPortmapClient portmap = new OncRpcPortmapClient(InetAddress.getByName("localhost"));
With the portmapper proxy object in our hands we can now ask for the port number of a particular ONC/RPC server. In this (ficious) example we ask for the ONC/RPC program (server) number 0x49678 (by coincidence this happens to be the program number of the ACPLT/KS protocol). To ask for the port number of a given program number, use the GetPort(...) method.
int port; try { port = portmap.getPort(0x49678, 1, OncRpcProtocols.ONCRPC_UDP); } catch ( OncRpcProgramNotRegisteredException e ) { System.out.println("ONC/RPC program server not found"); System.exit(0); } catch ( OncRpcException e ) { System.out.println("Could not contact portmapper:"); e.printStackTrace(System.out); System.exit(0); } System.out.println("Program available at port " + port);
In the call to GetPort(...) , the first parameter specifies the ONC/RPC program number, the second parameter specifies the program's version number, and the third parameter specifies the IP protocol to use when issueing ONC/RPC calls. Currently, only OncRpcProtocols.ONCRPC_UDP and OncRpcProtocols.ONCRPC_TCP are supported. But who needs other protocols anyway?!
In case GetPort(...) succeeds, it returns the number of the port where the appropriate ONC/RPC server waits for incoming ONC/RPC calls. If the ONC/RPC program is not registered with the particular ONC/RPC portmapper, an OncRpcProgramNotRegisteredException
is thrown (which is a subclass of OncRpcException with a detail reason of OncRpcException.RPC_PROGNOTREGISTERED
.
A second typical example of how to use the portmapper is retrieving a list of the currently registered servers. We use the ListServers() method for this purpose in the following example, and print the list we got.
OncRpcServerIdent [] list = null; try { list = portmap.listServers(); } catch ( OncRpcException e ) { e.printStackTrace(System.out); System.exit(20); } for ( int i = 0; i < list.length; ++i ) { System.out.println(list[i].program + " " + list[i].version + " " + list[i].protocol + " " + list[i].port); }
When you do not need the client proxy object any longer, you should return the resources it occupies to the system. Use the Close() method for this.
portmap.close(); portmap = null; // Hint to the garbage (wo)man
For another code example, please consult src/tests/org/acplt/oncrpc/PortmapGetPortTest.java. Converted to C# using the db4o Sharpen tool.
member.author: Harald Albrecht
Jay Walters

Timeout in milliseconds for connection operation. This parameter applies only when using TCP/IP for talking to the portmapper. A negative timeout indicates that the implementation-specific timeout setting of the JVM and java.net implementation should be used instead.

member.name: T:NFSLibrary.Rpc.OncRpcReplyMessage
member.summary: The OncRpcReplyMessage class represents an ONC/RPC reply message as defined by ONC/RPC in RFC 1831.
member.remarks:
The OncRpcReplyMessage class represents an ONC/RPC reply message as defined by ONC/RPC in RFC 1831. Such messages are sent back by ONC/RPC to servers to clients and contain (in case of real success) the result of a remote procedure call.
The decision to define only one single class for the accepted and rejected replies was driven by the motivation not to use polymorphism and thus have to upcast and downcast references all the time.
The derived classes are only provided for convinience on the server side. Converted to C# using the db4o Sharpen tool.
member.author: Harald Albrecht
Jay Walters

member.name: F:NFSLibrary.Rpc.OncRpcReplyMessage.replyStatus
member.summary: The reply status of the reply message.
member.remarks:
The reply status of the reply message. This can be either OncRpcReplyStatus.ONCRPC_MSG_ACCEPTED
or OncRpcReplyStatus.ONCRPC_MSG_DENIED
. Depending on the value of this field, other fields of an instance of OncRpcReplyMessage become important.
The decision to define only one single class for the accepted and rejected replies was driven by the motivation not to use polymorphism and thus have to upcast and downcast references all the time.

member.name: F:NFSLibrary.Rpc.OncRpcReplyMessage.acceptStatus
F:NFSLibrary.Rpc.OncRpcReplyMessage.rejectStatus
member.summary:
Rejectance status in case this reply sent in response to a rejected call ( OncRpcReplyStatus.ONCRPC_MSG_DENIED
). This field can take any of the values defined in the OncRpcRejectStatus interface.

member.name: F:NFSLibrary.Rpc.OncRpcReplyMessage.lowVersion
member.summary:
Lowest supported version in case of OncRpcRejectStatus.ONCRPC_RPC_MISMATCH
and OncRpcAcceptStatus.ONCRPC_PROG_MISMATCH
.

member.name: F:NFSLibrary.Rpc.OncRpcReplyMessage.highVersion
member.summary:
Highest supported version in case of OncRpcRejectStatus.ONCRPC_RPC_MISMATCH
and OncRpcAcceptStatus.ONCRPC_PROG_MISMATCH
.

member.name: F:NFSLibrary.Rpc.OncRpcReplyMessage.authStatus

Contains the reason for authentification failure in the case of OncRpcRejectStatus.ONCRPC_AUTH_ERROR

member.name: T:NFSLibrary.Rpc.OncRpcServerIdent
member.summary: The class OncRpcServerIdent represents an tuple { program, version, protocol, port} uniquely identifying a particular ONC/RPC server on a given host.
member.remarks:
The class OncRpcServerIdent represents an tuple { program, version, protocol, port} uniquely identifying a particular ONC/RPC server on a given host. This information is used, for instance, as the ONC/RPC portmap PMAP_GETPORT call parameters.
An OncRpcServerIdent can be directly serialized into an encoding XDR stream (that is more political correct than "flushed down the toilet"). Converted to C# using the db4o Sharpen tool.

Size of receive and send buffers. In contrast to UDP-based ONC/RPC clients, messages larger than the specified buffer size can still be sent and received. The buffer is only necessary to handle the messages and the underlaying streams will break up long messages automatically into suitable pieces. Specifying zero will select the default buffer size (currently 8192 bytes).
The local binding port will be less than 1024.

member.param: The host where the ONC/RPC server resides.
Program number of the ONC/RPC server to call.
The port number where the ONC/RPC server can be contacted. If 0, then the OncRpcUdpClient object will ask the portmapper at host for the port number.

Size of receive and send buffers. In contrast to UDP-based ONC/RPC clients, messages larger than the specified buffer size can still be sent and received. The buffer is only necessary to handle the messages and the underlaying streams will break up long messages automatically into suitable pieces. Specifying zero will select the default buffer size (currently 8192 bytes).

Maximum timeout in milliseconds when connecting to the ONC/RPC server. If negative, a default implementation-specific timeout setting will apply. Note that this timeout only applies to the connection phase, but not to later communication.
The local binding port will be less than 1024.

member.summary: Calls a remote procedure on an ONC/RPC server.
member.remarks:
Calls a remote procedure on an ONC/RPC server.
Please note that while this method supports call batching by setting the communication timeout to zero (setTimeout(0)) you should better use batchCall(int, XdrAble, bool) as it provides better control over when the batch should be flushed to the server.
member.param: Procedure number of the procedure to call.
The parameters of the procedure to call, contained in an object which implements the XdrAble interface.
The object receiving the result of the procedure call.

member.name: M:NFSLibrary.Rpc.OncRpcTcpClient.SetTimeout(System.Int32)
member.summary: Set the timout for remote procedure calls to wait for an answer from the ONC/RPC server.
member.remarks:
Set the timout for remote procedure calls to wait for an answer from the ONC/RPC server. If the timeout expires, OncRpcClient.call(int, XdrAble, XdrAble)
will raise a timeout exception. The default timeout value is 30 seconds (30,000 milliseconds). The timeout must be > 0. A timeout of zero indicates a batched call, for which no reply message is expected.
member.param: Timeout in milliseconds. A timeout of zero indicates batched calls.

member.name: M:NFSLibrary.Rpc.OncRpcUdpClient.call(System.Int32,System.Int32,NFSLibrary.Rpc.XdrAble,NFSLibrary.Rpc.XdrAble)
member.summary: Calls a remote procedure on an ONC/RPC server.
member.remarks:
Calls a remote procedure on an ONC/RPC server.
The OncRpcUdpClient uses a similar timeout scheme as the genuine Sun C implementation of ONC/RPC: it starts with a timeout of one second when waiting for a reply. If no reply is received within this time frame, the client doubles the timeout, sends a new request and then waits again for a reply. In every case the client will wait no longer than the total timeout set through the OncRpcClient.SetTimeout(int) method.
member.param: Procedure number of the procedure to call.
The parameters of the procedure to call, contained in an object which implements the XdrAble interface.
The object receiving the result of the procedure call.

member.name: M:NFSLibrary.Rpc.OncRpcUdpClient.broadcastCall(System.Int32,NFSLibrary.Rpc.XdrAble,NFSLibrary.Rpc.XdrAble,NFSLibrary.Rpc.OncRpcBroadcastListener)
member.summary: Broadcast a remote procedure call to several ONC/RPC servers.
member.remarks:
Broadcast a remote procedure call to several ONC/RPC servers. For this you'll need to specify either a multicast address or the subnet's broadcast address when creating a OncRpcUdpClient. For every reply received, an event containing the reply is sent to the OncRpcBroadcastListener listener, which is the last parameter to the this method.
In contrast to the OncRpcClient.call(int, XdrAble, XdrAble)
method, broadcastCall will only send the ONC/RPC call once. It will then wait for answers until the timeout as set by OncRpcClient.SetTimeout(int) expires without resending the reply.
Note that you might experience unwanted results when using authentication types other than OncRpcClientAuthNone , causing messed up authentication protocol handling objects. This depends on the type of authentication used. For AUTH_UNIX nothing bad happens as long as none of the servers replies with a shorthand verifier. If it does, then this shorthand will be used on all subsequent ONC/RPC calls, something you probably do not want at all.
member.param: Procedure number of the procedure to call.
The parameters of the procedure to call, contained in an object which implements the XdrAble interface.
The object receiving the result of the procedure call. Note that this object is reused to deserialize all incomming replies one after another.
Listener which will get an OncRpcBroadcastEvent for every reply received.

member.summary: Set the retransmission timout for remote procedure calls to wait for an answer from the ONC/RPC server before resending the call.
member.remarks: Set the retransmission timout for remote procedure calls to wait for an answer from the ONC/RPC server before resending the call. The default retransmission timeout is the 30 seconds. The retransmission timeout must be > 0. To disable retransmission of lost calls, set the retransmission timeout to be the same value as the timeout.
member.param: Timeout in milliseconds. A timeout of zero indicates batched calls.

member.name: F:NFSLibrary.Rpc.OncRpcUdpRetransmissionMode.EXPONENTIAL
member.summary: In exponentional back-off retransmission mode, UDP/IP-based ONC/RPC clients first wait a given retransmission timeout period before sending the ONC/RPC call again.

member.name: F:NFSLibrary.Rpc.OncRpcUdpRetransmissionMode.FIXED

member.remarks: In fixed retransmission mode, UDP/IP-based ONC/RPC clients wait a given retransmission timeout period before send the ONC/RPC call again. The retransmission timeout is not changed between consecutive tries but is fixed instead.

member.name: T:NFSLibrary.Rpc.Portmap.JPortmap
member.summary: The class jportmap implements a Java-based ONC/RPC port mapper, speaking the widely deployed protocol version 2.
member.remarks:
The class jportmap implements a Java-based ONC/RPC port mapper, speaking the widely deployed protocol version 2.
This class can be either used stand-alone (a static main is provided for this purpose) or as part of an application. In this case you should check first for another portmap already running before starting your own one. Converted to C# using the db4o Sharpen tool.

member.summary: Stop the embedded portmap service if it is running.
member.remarks:
Stop the embedded portmap service if it is running. Normaly you should not use this method except you need to force the embedded portmap service to terminate. Under normal conditions the thread responsible for the embedded portmap service will terminate automatically after the last ONC/RPC program has been deregistered.
This method just signals the portmap thread to stop processing ONC/RPC portmap calls and to terminate itself after it has cleaned up after itself.

member.name: T:NFSLibrary.Rpc.Server.OncRpcCallInformation
member.summary: Objects of class OncRpcCallInformation contain information about individual ONC/RPC calls.
member.remarks:
Objects of class OncRpcCallInformation contain information about individual ONC/RPC calls. They are given to ONC/RPC call dispatchers , so they can send back the reply to the appropriate caller, etc. Use only this call info objects to retrieve call parameters and send back replies as in the future UDP/IP-based transports may become multi-threaded handling. The call info object is responsible to control access to the underlaying transport, so never mess with the transport directly.
Note that this class provides two different patterns for accessing parameters sent by clients within the ONC/RPC call and sending back replies.
The convenient high-level access:
Use retrieveCall(NFSLibrary.Rpc.XdrAble)
to retrieve the parameters of the call and deserialize it into a paramter object.
Use reply(NFSLibrary.Rpc.XdrAble) to send back the reply by serializing a reply/result object. Or use the failXXX methods to send back an error indication instead.
The lower-level access, giving more control over how and when data is deserialized and serialized:
Use getXdrDecodingStream() to get a reference to the XDR stream from which you can deserialize the call's parameter.
When you are finished deserializing, call EndDecoding() .
To send back the reply/result, call BeginEncoding(OncRpcServerReplyMessage)
. Using the XDR stream returned by getXdrEncodingStream() serialize the reply/result. Finally finish the serializing step by calling EndEncoding() .
Converted to C# using the db4o Sharpen tool.
member.author: Harald Albrecht
Jay Walters

member.name: M:NFSLibrary.Rpc.Server.OncRpcCallInformation.#ctor(NFSLibrary.Rpc.Server.OncRpcServerTransport)
member.summary: Create an OncRpcCallInformation object and associate it with a ONC/RPC server transport.
member.remarks: Create an OncRpcCallInformation object and associate it with a ONC/RPC server transport. Typically, OncRpcCallInformation objects are created by transports once before handling incoming calls using the same call info object. To support multithreaded handling of calls in the future (for UDP/IP), the transport is already divided from the call info.

if an I/O exception occurs, like transmission failures over the network, etc.

member.name: M:NFSLibrary.Rpc.Server.OncRpcCallInformation.BeginEncoding(NFSLibrary.Rpc.Server.OncRpcServerReplyMessage)
member.summary: Begins the sending phase for ONC/RPC replies.
member.remarks:
Begins the sending phase for ONC/RPC replies. After beginning sending you can serialize the reply/result (but only if the call was accepted, see NFSLibrary.Rpc.OncRpcReplyMessage
for details). The stream to use for serialization can be obtained using getXdrEncodingStream() . This method belongs to the lower-level access pattern when handling ONC/RPC calls.
member.param: ONC/RPC reply header indicating success or failure.
member.exception: if an ONC/RPC exception occurs, like the data could not be successfully serialized.
if an I/O exception occurs, like transmission failures over the network, etc.

member.summary: Begins the sending phase for accepted ONC/RPC replies.
member.remarks: Begins the sending phase for accepted ONC/RPC replies. After beginning sending you can serialize the result/reply. The stream to use for serialization can be obtained using getXdrEncodingStream() . This method belongs to the lower-level access pattern when handling ONC/RPC calls.
member.exception: if an ONC/RPC exception occurs, like the data could not be successfully serialized.
if an I/O exception occurs, like transmission failures over the network, etc.

member.name: M:NFSLibrary.Rpc.Server.OncRpcDispatchable.DispatchOncRpcCall(NFSLibrary.Rpc.Server.OncRpcCallInformation,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Dispatch (handle) an ONC/RPC request from a client.
member.remarks:
Dispatch (handle) an ONC/RPC request from a client. This interface has some fairly deep semantics, so please read the description above for how to use it properly. For background information about fairly deep semantics, please also refer to Gigzales, J.: Semantics considered harmful. Addison-Reilly, 1992, ISBN 0-542-10815-X.
See the introduction to this class for examples of how to use this interface properly.
member.param: Information about the call to handle, like the caller's Internet address, the ONC/RPC call header, etc.

member.summary: The OncRpcServerAcceptedCallMessage class represents (on the sender's side) an accepted ONC/RPC call.
member.remarks:
The OncRpcServerAcceptedCallMessage class represents (on the sender's side) an accepted ONC/RPC call. In ONC/RPC babble, an "accepted" call does not mean that it carries a result from the remote procedure call, but rather that the call was accepted at the basic ONC/RPC level and no authentification failure or else occured.
This ONC/RPC reply header class is only a convenience for server implementors.
Converted to C# using the db4o Sharpen tool.
member.author: Harald Albrecht
Jay Walters

member.remarks: Constructs an OncRpcServerAcceptedCallMessage object which represents an accepted call, which was also successfully executed, so the reply will contain information from the remote procedure call.
member.param: The call message header, which is used to construct the matching reply message header from.

member.remarks: Constructs an OncRpcAcceptedCallMessage object which represents an accepted call, which was not necessarily successfully carried out. The parameter acceptStatus will then indicate the exact outcome of the ONC/RPC call.

member.name: T:NFSLibrary.Rpc.Server.OncRpcServerCallMessage
member.summary: The OncRpcServerCallMessage class represents an ONC/RPC call message on the server side.
member.remarks: The OncRpcServerCallMessage class represents an ONC/RPC call message on the server side. For this reasons it just handles decoding of call messages but can not do any encoding. This class is also responsible for pulling off authentication information from the wire and converting it into appropriate authentication protocol handling objects. As with all good management, this class therefor delegates this somehow unpleasant work to the server-side authentication protocol handling classes. Converted to C# using the db4o Sharpen tool.
member.author: Harald Albrecht
Jay Walters

member.param: A decoding XDR stream from which to receive all the mess.

member.name: T:NFSLibrary.Rpc.Server.OncRpcServerReplyMessage
member.summary: The OncRpcReplyMessage class represents an ONC/RPC reply message as defined by ONC/RPC in RFC 1831.
member.remarks:
The OncRpcReplyMessage class represents an ONC/RPC reply message as defined by ONC/RPC in RFC 1831. Such messages are sent back by ONC/RPC to servers to clients and contain (in case of real success) the result of a remote procedure call.
This class and all its derived classes can be encoded only. They are not able to encode themselves, because they are used solely on the server side of an ONC/RPC connection.
The decision to define only one single class for the accepted and rejected replies was driven by the motivation not to use polymorphism and thus have to upcast and downcast references all the time. Converted to C# using the db4o Sharpen tool.
member.author: Harald Albrecht
Jay Walters

member.name: M:NFSLibrary.Rpc.Server.OncRpcServerReplyMessage.#ctor(NFSLibrary.Rpc.Server.OncRpcServerCallMessage,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Initializes a new OncRpcReplyMessage object and initializes its complete state from the given parameters.
member.remarks:
Initializes a new OncRpcReplyMessage object and initializes its complete state from the given parameters.
Note that depending on the reply, acceptance and rejectance status some parameters are unused and can be specified as UNUSED_PARAMETER.
member.param: The ONC/RPC call this reply message corresponds to.

member.name: T:NFSLibrary.Rpc.Server.OncRpcServerTransport
member.summary: Instances of class OncRpcServerTransport encapsulate XDR streams of ONC/RPC servers.
member.remarks:
Instances of class OncRpcServerTransport encapsulate XDR streams of ONC/RPC servers. Using server transports, ONC/RPC calls are received and the corresponding replies are later sent back after handling.
Note that the server-specific dispatcher handling requests (done through OncRpcDispatchable will only directly deal with OncRpcCallInformation objects. These call information objects reference OncRpcServerTransport object, but the server programmer typically will never touch them, as the call information object already contains all necessary information about a call, so replies can be sent back (and this is definetely a sentence containing too many words). Converted to C# using the db4o Sharpen tool.
member.author: Harald Albrecht
Jay Walters

member.name: M:NFSLibrary.Rpc.Server.OncRpcServerTransport.#ctor(NFSLibrary.Rpc.Server.OncRpcDispatchable,System.Int32,NFSLibrary.Rpc.Server.OncRpcServerTransportRegistrationInfo[])
member.summary: Create a new instance of a OncRpcServerTransport which encapsulates XDR streams of an ONC/RPC server.
member.remarks:
Create a new instance of a OncRpcServerTransport which encapsulates XDR streams of an ONC/RPC server. Using a server transport, ONC/RPC calls are received and the corresponding replies are sent back.
We do not create any XDR streams here, as it is the responsibility of derived classes to create appropriate XDR stream objects for the respective kind of transport mechanism used (like TCP/IP and UDP/IP).
member.param: Reference to interface of an object capable of dispatching (handling) ONC/RPC calls.
Number of port where the server will wait for incoming calls.
Array of program and version number tuples of the ONC/RPC programs and versions handled by this transport.

member.name: M:NFSLibrary.Rpc.Server.OncRpcServerTransport.register
member.summary: Register the port where this server transport waits for incoming requests with the ONC/RPC portmapper.
member.remarks:
Register the port where this server transport waits for incoming requests with the ONC/RPC portmapper.
The contract of this method is, that derived classes implement the appropriate communication with the portmapper, so the transport is registered only for the protocol supported by a particular kind of server transport.
member.exception: if the portmapper could not be contacted successfully.

member.name: M:NFSLibrary.Rpc.Server.OncRpcServerTransport.unregister
member.summary: Unregisters the port where this server transport waits for incoming requests from the ONC/RPC portmapper.
member.remarks:
Unregisters the port where this server transport waits for incoming requests from the ONC/RPC portmapper.
Note that due to the way Sun decided to implement its ONC/RPC portmapper process, deregistering one server transports causes all entries for the same program and version to be removed, regardless of the protocol (UDP/IP or TCP/IP) used. Sigh.
member.exception:
with a reason of OncRpcException.RPC_FAILED
if the portmapper could not be contacted successfully. Note that it is not considered an error to remove a non-existing entry from the portmapper.

member.name: M:NFSLibrary.Rpc.Server.OncRpcServerTransport.Close
member.summary: Close the server transport and free any resources associated with it.
member.remarks:
Close the server transport and free any resources associated with it.
Note that the server transport is not deregistered. You'll have to do it manually if you need to do so. The reason for this behaviour is, that the portmapper removes all entries regardless of the protocol (TCP/IP or UDP/IP) for a given ONC/RPC program number and version.
Derived classes can choose between different behaviour for shuting down the associated transport handler threads:
Close the transport immediately and let the threads stumble on the closed network connection.
Wait for handler threads to complete their current ONC/RPC request (with timeout), then close connections and kill the threads.

member.name: M:NFSLibrary.Rpc.Server.OncRpcServerTransport.listen
member.summary: Creates a new thread and uses this thread to listen to incoming ONC/RPC requests, then dispatches them and finally sends back the appropriate reply messages.
member.remarks:
Creates a new thread and uses this thread to listen to incoming ONC/RPC requests, then dispatches them and finally sends back the appropriate reply messages.
Note that you have to supply an implementation for this abstract method in derived classes. Your implementation needs to create a new thread to wait for incoming requests. The method has to return immediately for the calling thread.

member.remarks: Returns port number of socket this server transport listens on for incoming ONC/RPC calls.
member.returns: Port number of socket listening for incoming calls.

member.name: M:NFSLibrary.Rpc.Server.OncRpcServerTransport.retrieveCall(NFSLibrary.Rpc.XdrAble)
member.summary: Retrieves the parameters sent within an ONC/RPC call message.
member.remarks:
Retrieves the parameters sent within an ONC/RPC call message. It also makes sure that the deserialization process is properly finished after the call parameters have been retrieved. Under the hood this method therefore calls NFSLibrary.Rpc.XdrDecodingStream.EndDecoding()
to free any pending resources from the decoding stage.
member.exception: if an ONC/RPC exception occurs, like the data could not be successfully deserialized.
if an I/O exception occurs, like transmission failures over the network, etc.

member.name: M:NFSLibrary.Rpc.Server.OncRpcServerTransport.getXdrDecodingStream
member.summary: Returns XDR stream which can be used for deserializing the parameters of this ONC/RPC call.
member.remarks: Returns XDR stream which can be used for deserializing the parameters of this ONC/RPC call. This method belongs to the lower-level access pattern when handling ONC/RPC calls.
member.returns: Reference to decoding XDR stream.

member.name: M:NFSLibrary.Rpc.Server.OncRpcServerTransport.EndDecoding

member.name: M:NFSLibrary.Rpc.Server.OncRpcServerTransport.reply(NFSLibrary.Rpc.Server.OncRpcCallInformation,NFSLibrary.Rpc.Server.OncRpcServerReplyMessage,NFSLibrary.Rpc.XdrAble)
member.summary: Send back an ONC/RPC reply to the original caller.
member.remarks:
Send back an ONC/RPC reply to the original caller. This is rather a low-level method, typically not used by applications. Dispatcher handling ONC/RPC calls have to use the OncRpcCallInformation.reply(NFSLibrary.Rpc.XdrAble)
method instead on the call object supplied to the handler.
An appropriate implementation has to be provided in derived classes as it is dependent on the type of transport (whether UDP/IP or TCP/IP) used.
member.param: information about the original call, which are necessary to send back the reply to the appropriate caller.
ONC/RPC reply message header indicating success or failure and containing associated state information.
If not null, then this parameter references the reply to be serialized after the reply message header.
member.exception: if an ONC/RPC exception occurs, like the data could not be successfully serialized.
if an I/O exception occurs, like transmission failures over the network, etc.

member.name: M:NFSLibrary.Rpc.Server.OncRpcTcpConnectionServerTransport.Close
member.summary: Close the server transport and free any resources associated with it.
member.remarks:
Close the server transport and free any resources associated with it.
Note that the server transport is not deregistered. You'll have to do it manually if you need to do so. The reason for this behaviour is, that the portmapper removes all entries regardless of the protocol (TCP/IP or UDP/IP) for a given ONC/RPC program number and version.
Calling this method on a OncRpcTcpServerTransport results in the listening TCP network socket immediately being closed. The handler thread will therefore either terminate directly or when it tries to sent back replies.

member.name: M:NFSLibrary.Rpc.Server.OncRpcTcpConnectionServerTransport.retrieveCall(NFSLibrary.Rpc.XdrAble)
member.summary: Retrieves the parameters sent within an ONC/RPC call message.
member.remarks:
Retrieves the parameters sent within an ONC/RPC call message. It also makes sure that the deserialization process is properly finished after the call parameters have been retrieved. Under the hood this method therefore calls NFSLibrary.Rpc.XdrDecodingStream.EndDecoding()
to free any pending resources from the decoding stage.
member.exception: if an ONC/RPC exception occurs, like the data could not be successfully deserialized.
if an I/O exception occurs, like transmission failures over the network, etc.
