member.name: M:NFSLibrary.Rpc.Server.OncRpcTcpConnectionServerTransport.listen
member.summary: Creates a new thread and uses this thread to handle the new connection to receive ONC/RPC requests, then dispatching them and finally sending back reply messages.
member.remarks:
Creates a new thread and uses this thread to handle the new connection to receive ONC/RPC requests, then dispatching them and finally sending back reply messages. Control in the calling thread immediately returns after the handler thread has been created.
Currently only one call after the other is dispatched, so no multithreading is done when receiving multiple calls. Instead, later calls have to wait for the current call to finish before they are handled.

member.summary: Create a new instance of a OncRpcTcpServerTransport which encapsulates TCP/IP-based XDR streams of an ONC/RPC server.
member.remarks:
Create a new instance of a OncRpcTcpServerTransport which encapsulates TCP/IP-based XDR streams of an ONC/RPC server. This particular server transport only waits for incoming connection requests and then creates OncRpcTcpConnectionServerTransport
server transports to handle individual connections. This constructor is a convenience constructor for those transports handling only a single ONC/RPC program and version number.
member.param: Reference to interface of an object capable of dispatching (handling) ONC/RPC calls.
Number of port where the server will wait for incoming calls.
Number of ONC/RPC program handled by this server transport.
Version number of ONC/RPC program handled.

member.summary: Create a new instance of a OncRpcTcpServerTransport which encapsulates TCP/IP-based XDR streams of an ONC/RPC server.
member.remarks:
Create a new instance of a OncRpcTcpServerTransport which encapsulates TCP/IP-based XDR streams of an ONC/RPC server. This particular server transport only waits for incoming connection requests and then creates OncRpcTcpConnectionServerTransport
server transports to handle individual connections.
member.param: Reference to interface of an object capable of dispatching (handling) ONC/RPC calls.
The local Internet Address the server will bind to.
Number of port where the server will wait for incoming calls.

member.name: M:NFSLibrary.Rpc.Server.OncRpcTcpServerTransport.Close
member.summary: Close the server transport and free any resources associated with it.
member.remarks:
Close the server transport and free any resources associated with it.
Note that the server transport is not deregistered. You'll have to do it manually if you need to do so. The reason for this behaviour is, that the portmapper removes all entries regardless of the protocol (TCP/IP or UDP/IP) for a given ONC/RPC program number and version.
Calling this method on a OncRpcTcpServerTransport results in the listening TCP network socket immediately being closed. In addition, all server transports handling the individual TCP/IP connections will also be closed. The handler threads will therefore either terminate directly or when they try to sent back replies.

member.summary: Creates a new thread and uses this thread to listen to incoming ONC/RPC requests, then dispatches them and finally sends back the appropriate reply messages.
member.remarks:
Creates a new thread and uses this thread to listen to incoming ONC/RPC requests, then dispatches them and finally sends back the appropriate reply messages. Control in the calling thread immediately returns after the handler thread has been created.
For every incomming TCP/IP connection a handler thread is created to handle ONC/RPC calls on this particular connection.

member.name: T:NFSLibrary.Rpc.Server.OncRpcTcpServerTransport.TransportList
member.summary: Minumum implementation of a double linked list which notices which transports are currently open and have to be shut down when this listening transport is shut down.
member.remarks:
Minumum implementation of a double linked list which notices which transports are currently open and have to be shut down when this listening transport is shut down. The only reason why we have this code here instead of using java.util.LinkedList is due to JDK 1.1 compatibility.
Note that the methods are not synchronized as we leave this up to the caller, who can thus optimize access during critical sections.

member.remarks: Create a new instance of a OncRpcUdpServerTransport which encapsulates UDP/IP-based XDR streams of an ONC/RPC server. Using a server transport, ONC/RPC calls are received and the corresponding replies are sent back. This constructor is a convenience constructor for those transports handling only a single ONC/RPC program and version number.

Version number of ONC/RPC program handled.
Size of buffer for receiving and sending UDP/IP datagrams containing ONC/RPC call and reply messages.

member.name: M:NFSLibrary.Rpc.Server.OncRpcUdpServerTransport.Close
member.summary: Close the server transport and free any resources associated with it.
member.remarks:
Close the server transport and free any resources associated with it.
Note that the server transport is not deregistered. You'll have to do it manually if you need to do so. The reason for this behaviour is, that the portmapper removes all entries regardless of the protocol (TCP/IP or UDP/IP) for a given ONC/RPC program number and version.
Calling this method on a OncRpcUdpServerTransport results in the UDP network socket immediately being closed. The handler thread will therefore either terminate directly or when it tries to sent back a reply which it was about to handle at the time the close method was called.

member.name: M:NFSLibrary.Rpc.Server.OncRpcUdpServerTransport.register
member.summary: Register the UDP/IP port where this server transport waits for incoming requests with the ONC/RPC portmapper.
member.remarks: Register the UDP/IP port where this server transport waits for incoming requests with the ONC/RPC portmapper.
member.exception: if the portmapper could not be contacted successfully.

member.name: M:NFSLibrary.Rpc.Server.OncRpcUdpServerTransport.retrieveCall(NFSLibrary.Rpc.XdrAble)
member.summary: Retrieves the parameters sent within an ONC/RPC call message.
member.remarks:
Retrieves the parameters sent within an ONC/RPC call message. It also makes sure that the deserialization process is properly finished after the call parameters have been retrieved. Under the hood this method therefore calls NFSLibrary.Rpc.XdrDecodingStream.EndDecoding()
to free any pending resources from the decoding stage.
member.exception: if an ONC/RPC exception occurs, like the data could not be successfully deserialized.
if an I/O exception occurs, like transmission failures over the network, etc.

member.returns: Reference to decoding XDR stream.

member.remarks: Finishes call parameter deserialization. Afterwards the XDR stream returned by getXdrDecodingStream() must not be used any more. This method belongs to the lower-level access pattern when handling ONC/RPC calls.
member.exception: if an ONC/RPC exception occurs, like the data could not be successfully deserialized.
if an I/O exception occurs, like transmission failures over the network, etc.

member.name: M:NFSLibrary.Rpc.Server.OncRpcUdpServerTransport.reply(NFSLibrary.Rpc.Server.OncRpcCallInformation,NFSLibrary.Rpc.Server.OncRpcServerReplyMessage,NFSLibrary.Rpc.XdrAble)
member.summary: Send back an ONC/RPC reply to the original caller.
member.remarks:
Send back an ONC/RPC reply to the original caller. This is rather a low-level method, typically not used by applications. Dispatcher handling ONC/RPC calls have to use the OncRpcCallInformation.reply(NFSLibrary.Rpc.XdrAble)
method instead on the call object supplied to the handler.
member.param: information about the original call, which are necessary to send back the reply to the appropriate caller.
ONC/RPC reply message header indicating success or failure and containing associated state information.
If not null, then this parameter references the reply to be serialized after the reply message header.
member.exception: if an ONC/RPC exception occurs, like the data could not be successfully serialized.
if an I/O exception occurs, like transmission failures over the network, etc.

member.name: M:NFSLibrary.Rpc.Server.OncRpcUdpServerTransport.listen
member.summary: Creates a new thread and uses this thread to listen to incoming ONC/RPC requests, then dispatches them and finally sends back the appropriate reply messages.
member.remarks:
Creates a new thread and uses this thread to listen to incoming ONC/RPC requests, then dispatches them and finally sends back the appropriate reply messages. Control in the calling thread immediately returns after the handler thread has been created.
Currently only one call after the other is dispatched, so no multithreading is done when receiving multiple calls. Instead, later calls have to wait for the current call to finish before they are handled.

member.name: T:NFSLibrary.Rpc.XdrBoolean
member.summary: Instances of the class XdrBoolean represent (de-)serializeable booleans, which are especially useful in cases where a result with only a single boolean is expected from a remote function call or only a single boolean parameter needs to be supplied.
member.remarks:
Instances of the class XdrBoolean represent (de-)serializeable booleans, which are especially useful in cases where a result with only a single boolean is expected from a remote function call or only a single boolean parameter needs to be supplied.
Please note that this class is somewhat modelled after Java's primitive data type wrappers. As for these classes, the XDR data type wrapper classes follow the concept of values with no identity, so you are not allowed to change the value after you've created a value object. Converted to C# using the db4o Sharpen tool.

member.summary: Initiates decoding of the next XDR record.
member.remarks: Initiates decoding of the next XDR record.

member.name: M:NFSLibrary.Rpc.XdrBufferDecodingStream.EndDecoding
member.summary: End decoding of the current XDR record.
member.remarks:
End decoding of the current XDR record. The general contract of endDecoding is that calling it is an indication that the current record is no more interesting to the caller and any allocated data for this record can be freed.
This method overrides XdrDecodingStream.EndDecoding() . It does nothing more than resetting the buffer pointer (eeek! a pointer in Java!!!) back to the begin of an empty buffer, so attempts to decode data will fail until the buffer is filled again.

member.name: M:NFSLibrary.Rpc.XdrBufferDecodingStream.Close
member.summary: Closes this decoding XDR stream and releases any system resources associated with this stream.
member.remarks:
Closes this decoding XDR stream and releases any system resources associated with this stream. A closed XDR stream cannot perform decoding operations and cannot be reopened.
This implementation frees the allocated buffer.

member.name: M:NFSLibrary.Rpc.XdrBufferDecodingStream.XdrDecodeInt
member.summary: Decodes (aka "deserializes") a "XDR int" value received from a XDR stream.
member.remarks: Decodes (aka "deserializes") a "XDR int" value received from a XDR stream. A XDR int is 32 bits wide -- the same width Java's "int" data type has.
member.returns: The decoded int value.

member.name: M:NFSLibrary.Rpc.XdrBufferDecodingStream.XdrDecodeOpaque(System.Int32)
member.summary: Decodes (aka "deserializes") an opaque value, which is nothing more than a series of octets (or 8 bits wide bytes).
member.remarks: Decodes (aka "deserializes") an opaque value, which is nothing more than a series of octets (or 8 bits wide bytes). Because the length of the opaque value is given, we don't need to retrieve it from the XDR stream. This is different from XdrDecodeOpaque(byte[], int, int) where first the length of the opaque value is retrieved from the XDR stream.
member.param: Length of opaque data to decode.
member.returns: Opaque data as a byte vector.

member.remarks: Decodes (aka "deserializes") a XDR opaque value, which is represented by a vector of byte values, and starts at offset with a length of length. Only the opaque value is decoded, so the caller has to know how long the opaque value will be. The decoded data is always padded to be a multiple of four (because that's what the sender does).
member.param: Byte vector which will receive the decoded opaque value.
Start offset in the byte vector.
the number of bytes to decode.

member.remarks: Encodes (aka "serializes") a "XDR int" value and writes it down a XDR stream. A XDR int is 32 bits wide -- the same width Java's "int" data type has. This method is one of the basic methods all other methods can rely on.

Only the opaque value is encoded, but no length indication is preceeding the opaque value, so the receiver has to know how long the opaque value will be. The encoded data is always padded to be a multiple of four. If the given length is not a multiple of four, zero bytes will be used for padding.

member.summary: Instances of the class XdrByte represent (de-)serializeable bytes, which are especially useful in cases where a result with only a single byte is expected from a remote function call or only a single byte parameter needs to be supplied.
member.remarks:
Instances of the class XdrByte represent (de-)serializeable bytes, which are especially useful in cases where a result with only a single byte is expected from a remote function call or only a single byte parameter needs to be supplied.
Please note that this class is somewhat modelled after Java's primitive data type wrappers. As for these classes, the XDR data type wrapper classes follow the concept of values with no identity, so you are not allowed to change the value after you've created a value object. Converted to C# using the db4o Sharpen tool.

member.name: T:NFSLibrary.Rpc.XdrDecodingStream
member.summary: Defines the abstract base class for all decoding XDR streams.
member.remarks:
Defines the abstract base class for all decoding XDR streams. A decoding XDR stream returns data in the form of Java data types which it reads from a data source (for instance, network or memory buffer) in the platform-independent XDR format.
Derived classes need to implement the XdrDecodeInt() , XdrDecodeOpaque(int) and XdrDecodeOpaque(byte[], int, int) methods to make this complete mess workable. Converted to C# using the db4o Sharpen tool.
member.author: Harald Albrecht
Jay Walters

member.name: M:NFSLibrary.Rpc.XdrDecodingStream.GetSenderAddress
member.summary: Returns the Internet address of the sender of the current XDR data.
member.remarks: Returns the Internet address of the sender of the current XDR data. This method should only be called after BeginDecoding() , otherwise it might return stale information.
member.returns: InetAddress of the sender of the current XDR data.

member.name: M:NFSLibrary.Rpc.XdrDecodingStream.GetSenderPort
member.summary: Returns the port number of the sender of the current XDR data.
member.remarks: Returns the port number of the sender of the current XDR data. This method should only be called after BeginDecoding() , otherwise it might return stale information.
member.returns: Port number of the sender of the current XDR data.

member.name: M:NFSLibrary.Rpc.XdrDecodingStream.BeginDecoding
member.summary: Initiates decoding of the next XDR record.
member.remarks: Initiates decoding of the next XDR record. This typically involves filling the internal buffer with the next datagram from the network, or reading the next chunk of data from a stream-oriented connection. In case of memory-based communication this might involve waiting for some other process to fill the buffer and signal availability of new XDR data.

member.name: M:NFSLibrary.Rpc.XdrDecodingStream.EndDecoding
member.summary: End decoding of the current XDR record.
member.remarks:
End decoding of the current XDR record. The general contract of endDecoding is that calling it is an indication that the current record is no more interesting to the caller and any allocated data for this record can be freed.
The endDecoding method of XdrDecodingStream does nothing.

member.name: M:NFSLibrary.Rpc.XdrDecodingStream.Close
member.summary: Closes this decoding XDR stream and releases any system resources associated with this stream.
member.remarks:
Closes this decoding XDR stream and releases any system resources associated with this stream. The general contract of close is that it closes the decoding XDR stream. A closed XDR stream cannot perform decoding operations and cannot be reopened.
The close method of XdrDecodingStream does nothing.

member.name: M:NFSLibrary.Rpc.XdrDecodingStream.XdrDecodeInt
member.summary: Decodes (aka "deserializes") a "XDR int" value received from a XDR stream.
member.remarks: Decodes (aka "deserializes") a "XDR int" value received from a XDR stream. A XDR int is 32 bits wide -- the same width Java's "int" data type has. This method is one of the basic methods all other methods can rely on. Because it's so basic, derived classes have to implement it.
member.returns: The decoded int value.

member.name: M:NFSLibrary.Rpc.XdrDecodingStream.XdrDecodeOpaque(System.Int32)
member.summary: Decodes (aka "deserializes") an opaque value, which is nothing more than a series of octets (or 8 bits wide bytes).
member.remarks:
Decodes (aka "deserializes") an opaque value, which is nothing more than a series of octets (or 8 bits wide bytes). Because the length of the opaque value is given, we don't need to retrieve it from the XDR stream.
Note that this is a basic abstract method, which needs to be implemented in derived classes.
member.param: Length of opaque data to decode.
member.returns: Opaque data as a byte vector.

member.name: M:NFSLibrary.Rpc.XdrDecodingStream.XdrDecodeOpaque(System.Byte[],System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Decodes (aka "deserializes") a XDR opaque value, which is represented by a vector of byte values, and starts at offset with a length of length.
member.remarks:
Decodes (aka "deserializes") a XDR opaque value, which is represented by a vector of byte values, and starts at offset with a length of length. Only the opaque value is decoded, so the caller has to know how long the opaque value will be. The decoded data is always padded to be a multiple of four (because that's what the sender does).
Derived classes must ensure that the proper semantic is maintained.
member.param: Byte vector which will receive the decoded opaque value.
Start offset in the byte vector.
the number of bytes to decode.
member.exception: if the given opaque byte vector isn't large enough to receive the result.

member.name: M:NFSLibrary.Rpc.XdrDecodingStream.XdrDecodeOpaque(System.Byte[])
member.summary: Decodes (aka "deserializes") a XDR opaque value, which is represented by a vector of byte values.
member.remarks: Decodes (aka "deserializes") a XDR opaque value, which is represented by a vector of byte values. Only the opaque value is decoded, so the caller has to know how long the opaque value will be. The decoded data is always padded to be a multiple of four (because that's what the sender does).
member.param: Byte vector which will receive the decoded opaque value.

member.name: M:NFSLibrary.Rpc.XdrDecodingStream.XdrDecodeDynamicOpaque
member.summary: Decodes (aka "deserializes") a XDR opaque value, which is represented by a vector of byte values.
member.remarks: Decodes (aka "deserializes") a XDR opaque value, which is represented by a vector of byte values. The length of the opaque value to decode is pulled off of the XDR stream, so the caller does not need to know the exact length in advance. The decoded data is always padded to be a multiple of four (because that's what the sender does).
member.returns: The byte vector containing the decoded data.

member.name: M:NFSLibrary.Rpc.XdrDecodingStream.XdrDecodeByteVector
member.summary: Decodes (aka "deserializes") a vector of bytes, which is nothing more than a series of octets (or 8 bits wide bytes), each packed into its very own 4 bytes (XDR int).
member.remarks: Decodes (aka "deserializes") a vector of bytes, which is nothing more than a series of octets (or 8 bits wide bytes), each packed into its very own 4 bytes (XDR int). Byte vectors are decoded together with a preceeding length value. This way the receiver doesn't need to know the length of the vector in advance.
member.returns: The byte vector containing the decoded data.

member.returns: The byte vector containing the decoded data.

member.name: T:NFSLibrary.Rpc.XdrEncodingStream
member.summary: Defines the abstract base class for all encoding XDR streams.
member.remarks:
Defines the abstract base class for all encoding XDR streams. An encoding XDR stream receives data in the form of Java data types and writes it to a data sink (for instance, network or memory buffer) in the platform-independent XDR format.
Derived classes need to implement the XdrEncodeInt(int) , XdrEncodeOpaque(byte[]) and XdrEncodeOpaque(byte[], int, int) methods to make this complete mess workable. Converted to C# using the db4o Sharpen tool.
member.author: Harald Albrecht
Jay Walters

member.name: M:NFSLibrary.Rpc.XdrEncodingStream.BeginEncoding(System.Net.IPAddress,System.Int32)
member.summary: Begins encoding a new XDR record.
member.remarks: Begins encoding a new XDR record. This typically involves resetting this encoding XDR stream back into a known state.
member.param: Indicates the receiver of the XDR data. This can be null for XDR streams connected permanently to a receiver (like in case of TCP/IP based XDR streams).

member.name: M:NFSLibrary.Rpc.XdrEncodingStream.EndEncoding
member.summary: Flushes this encoding XDR stream and forces any buffered output bytes to be written out.
member.remarks:
Flushes this encoding XDR stream and forces any buffered output bytes to be written out. The general contract of endEncoding is that calling it is an indication that the current record is finished and any bytes previously encoded should immediately be written to their intended destination.
The endEncoding method of XdrEncodingStream does nothing.

member.name: M:NFSLibrary.Rpc.XdrEncodingStream.Close
member.summary: Closes this encoding XDR stream and releases any system resources associated with this stream.
member.remarks:
Closes this encoding XDR stream and releases any system resources associated with this stream. The general contract of close is that it closes the encoding XDR stream. A closed XDR stream cannot perform encoding operations and cannot be reopened.
The close method of XdrEncodingStream does nothing.

member.name: M:NFSLibrary.Rpc.XdrEncodingStream.XdrEncodeInt(System.Int32)
member.summary: Encodes (aka "serializes") a "XDR int" value and writes it down a XDR stream.
member.remarks: Encodes (aka "serializes") a "XDR int" value and writes it down a XDR stream. A XDR int is 32 bits wide -- the same width Java's "int" data type has. This method is one of the basic methods all other methods can rely on. Because it's so basic, derived classes have to implement it.
member.param: The int value to be encoded.

member.name: M:NFSLibrary.Rpc.XdrEncodingStream.XdrEncodeOpaque(System.Byte[],System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Encodes (aka "serializes") a XDR opaque value, which is represented by a vector of byte values, and starts at offset with a length of length.
member.remarks:
Encodes (aka "serializes") a XDR opaque value, which is represented by a vector of byte values, and starts at offset with a length of length. Only the opaque value is encoded, but no length indication is preceeding the opaque value, so the receiver has to know how long the opaque value will be. The encoded data is always padded to be a multiple of four. If the given length is not a multiple of four, zero bytes will be used for padding.
Derived classes must ensure that the proper semantic is maintained.
member.param: The opaque value to be encoded in the form of a series of bytes.
the number of bytes to encode.

member.name: M:NFSLibrary.Rpc.XdrEncodingStream.XdrEncodeDynamicOpaque(System.Byte[])
member.summary: Encodes (aka "serializes") a XDR opaque value, which is represented by a vector of byte values.
member.remarks: Encodes (aka "serializes") a XDR opaque value, which is represented by a vector of byte values. The length of the opaque value is written to the XDR stream, so the receiver does not need to know the exact length in advance. The encoded data is always padded to be a multiple of four to maintain XDR alignment.
member.param: The opaque value to be encoded in the form of a series of bytes.

member.name: M:NFSLibrary.Rpc.XdrEncodingStream.XdrEncodeOpaque(System.Byte[])
member.summary: Encodes (aka "serializes") a XDR opaque value, which is represented by a vector of byte values.
member.remarks: Encodes (aka "serializes") a XDR opaque value, which is represented by a vector of byte values. Only the opaque value is encoded, but no length indication is preceeding the opaque value, so the receiver has to know how long the opaque value will be. The encoded data is always padded to be a multiple of four. If the length of the given byte vector is not a multiple of four, zero bytes will be used for padding.
member.param: The opaque value to be encoded in the form of a series of bytes.

member.name: M:NFSLibrary.Rpc.XdrEncodingStream.XdrEncodeByteVector(System.Byte[])
member.summary: Encodes (aka "serializes") a vector of bytes, which is nothing more than a series of octets (or 8 bits wide bytes), each packed into its very own 4 bytes (XDR int).
member.remarks: Encodes (aka "serializes") a vector of bytes, which is nothing more than a series of octets (or 8 bits wide bytes), each packed into its very own 4 bytes (XDR int). Byte vectors are encoded together with a preceeding length value. This way the receiver doesn't need to know the length of the vector in advance.

member.name: T:NFSLibrary.Rpc.XdrFloat
member.summary: Instances of the class XdrFloat represent (de-)serializeable floats, which are especially useful in cases where a result with only a single float is expected from a remote function call or only a single float parameter needs to be supplied.
member.remarks:
Instances of the class XdrFloat represent (de-)serializeable floats, which are especially useful in cases where a result with only a single float is expected from a remote function call or only a single float parameter needs to be supplied.
Please note that this class is somewhat modelled after Java's primitive data type wrappers. As for these classes, the XDR data type wrapper classes follow the concept of values with no identity, so you are not allowed to change the value after you've created a value object. Converted to C# using the db4o Sharpen tool.
member.author: Harald Albrecht
Jay Walters

member.summary: Returns the port number of the sender of the current XDR data.
member.remarks: Returns the port number of the sender of the current XDR data. This method should only be called after BeginDecoding , otherwise it might return stale information.
member.returns: Port number of the sender of the current XDR data.

member.name: M:NFSLibrary.Rpc.XdrTcpDecodingStream.BeginDecoding
member.summary: Initiates decoding of the next XDR record.
member.remarks:
Initiates decoding of the next XDR record. For TCP-based XDR decoding streams this reads in the next chunk of data from the network socket (a chunk of data is not necessary the same as a fragment, just enough to fill the internal buffer or receive the remaining part of a fragment).
Read in the next bunch of bytes. This can be either a complete fragment, or if the fragments sent by the communication partner are too large for our buffer, only parts of fragments. In every case, this method ensures that there will be more data available in the buffer (or else an exception thrown).

member.name: M:NFSLibrary.Rpc.XdrTcpDecodingStream.readBuffer(System.IO.Stream,System.Byte[],System.Int32)
member.summary: Read into buffer exactly the amount of bytes specified.
member.remarks: Read into buffer exactly the amount of bytes specified.
member.param: Input stream to read byte data from.
number of bytes to read into buffer.
member.exception: if EOF is reached before all bytes could be read.

member.name: M:NFSLibrary.Rpc.XdrTcpDecodingStream.fill
member.summary: Fills the internal buffer with the next chunk of data.
member.remarks:
Fills the internal buffer with the next chunk of data. The chunk is either as long as the buffer or as long as the remaining part of the current XDR fragment, whichever is smaller.
This method does not accept empty XDR record fragments with the only exception of a final trailing empty fragment. This special case is accepted as some ONC/RPC implementations emit such trailing empty fragments whenever the encoded data is a full multiple of their internal record buffer size.

member.name: M:NFSLibrary.Rpc.XdrTcpDecodingStream.EndDecoding
member.summary: End decoding of the current XDR record.
member.remarks:
End decoding of the current XDR record. The general contract of endDecoding is that calling it is an indication that the current record is no more interesting to the caller and any allocated data for this record can be freed.
This method overrides XdrDecodingStream.EndDecoding . It reads in and throws away fragments until it reaches the last fragment.

member.name: M:NFSLibrary.Rpc.XdrTcpDecodingStream.Close
member.summary: Closes this decoding XDR stream and releases any system resources associated with this stream.
member.remarks:
Closes this decoding XDR stream and releases any system resources associated with this stream. A closed XDR stream cannot perform decoding operations and cannot be reopened.
This implementation frees the allocated buffer but does not close the associated datagram socket. It only throws away the reference to this socket.

member.name: M:NFSLibrary.Rpc.XdrTcpDecodingStream.XdrDecodeInt
member.summary: Decodes (aka "deserializes") a "XDR int" value received from a XDR stream.
member.remarks: Decodes (aka "deserializes") a "XDR int" value received from a XDR stream. A XDR int is 32 bits wide -- the same width Java's "int" data type has.
member.returns: The decoded int value.

member.name: M:NFSLibrary.Rpc.XdrTcpDecodingStream.XdrDecodeOpaque(System.Int32)
member.summary: Decodes (aka "deserializes") an opaque value, which is nothing more than a series of octets (or 8 bits wide bytes).
member.remarks: Decodes (aka "deserializes") an opaque value, which is nothing more than a series of octets (or 8 bits wide bytes). Because the length of the opaque value is given, we don't need to retrieve it from the XDR stream. This is different from XdrDecodeOpaque(byte[], int, int) where first the length of the opaque value is retrieved from the XDR stream.
member.param: Length of opaque data to decode.
member.returns: Opaque data as a byte vector.

member.name: M:NFSLibrary.Rpc.XdrTcpDecodingStream.XdrDecodeOpaque(System.Byte[],System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Decodes (aka "deserializes") a XDR opaque value, which is represented by a vector of byte values, and starts at offset with a length of length.
member.remarks: Decodes (aka "deserializes") a XDR opaque value, which is represented by a vector of byte values, and starts at offset with a length of length. Only the opaque value is decoded, so the caller has to know how long the opaque value will be. The decoded data is always padded to be a multiple of four (because that's what the sender does).
member.param: Byte vector which will receive the decoded opaque value.
Start offset in the byte vector.
the number of bytes to decode.

member.name: M:NFSLibrary.Rpc.XdrTcpEncodingStream.BeginEncoding(System.Net.IPAddress,System.Int32)
member.summary: Begins encoding a new XDR record.
member.remarks: Begins encoding a new XDR record. This typically involves resetting this encoding XDR stream back into a known state.
member.param: Indicates the receiver of the XDR data. This can be null for XDR streams connected permanently to a receiver (like in case of TCP/IP based XDR streams).

member.name: M:NFSLibrary.Rpc.XdrTcpEncodingStream.EndEncoding
member.summary: Flushes this encoding XDR stream and forces any buffered output bytes to be written out.
member.remarks: Flushes this encoding XDR stream and forces any buffered output bytes to be written out. The general contract of endEncoding is that calling it is an indication that the current record is finished and any bytes previously encoded should immediately be written to their intended destination.

member.name: M:NFSLibrary.Rpc.XdrTcpEncodingStream.EndEncoding(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Ends the current record for this encoding XDR stream.
member.remarks: Ends the current record for this encoding XDR stream. If the parameter flush is true any buffered output bytes are immediately written to their intended destination. If flush is false, then more than one record can be pipelined, for instance, to batch several ONC/RPC calls. In this case the ONC/RPC server must not send a reply (with the exception for the last call in a batch, which might be trigger a reply). Otherwise, you will most probably cause an interaction deadlock between client and server.
member.param: Whether to flush the buffer to the network.

member.name: M:NFSLibrary.Rpc.XdrTcpEncodingStream.flush(System.Boolean,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Flushes the current contents of the buffer as one fragment to the network.
member.remarks: Flushes the current contents of the buffer as one fragment to the network.
member.param: true if this is the last fragment of the current XDR record.
if last fragment and batch is true, then the buffer is not flushed to the network but instead we wait for more records to be encoded.

member.summary: Closes this encoding XDR stream and releases any system resources associated with this stream.
member.remarks: Closes this encoding XDR stream and releases any system resources associated with this stream. The general contract of close is that it closes the encoding XDR stream. A closed XDR stream cannot perform encoding operations and cannot be reopened.

member.remarks: Encodes (aka "serializes") a "XDR int" value and writes it down a XDR stream. A XDR int is 32 bits wide -- the same width Java's "int" data type has. This method is one of the basic methods all other methods can rely on.

member.name: M:NFSLibrary.Rpc.XdrTcpEncodingStream.XdrEncodeOpaque(System.Byte[],System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Encodes (aka "serializes") a XDR opaque value, which is represented by a vector of byte values, and starts at offset with a length of length.
member.remarks: Encodes (aka "serializes") a XDR opaque value, which is represented by a vector of byte values, and starts at offset with a length of length. Only the opaque value is encoded, but no length indication is preceeding the opaque value, so the receiver has to know how long the opaque value will be. The encoded data is always padded to be a multiple of four. If the given length is not a multiple of four, zero bytes will be used for padding.

member.summary: End decoding of the current XDR record.

End decoding of the current XDR record. The general contract of endDecoding is that calling it is an indication that the current record is no more interesting to the caller and any allocated data for this record can be freed.
This method overrides XdrDecodingStream.EndDecoding . It does nothing more than resetting the buffer pointer (eeek! a pointer in Java!!!) back to the begin of an empty buffer, so attempts to decode data will fail until the buffer is filled again.

member.name: T:NFSLibrary.Rpc.XdrUnion
member.summary: The abstract base class XdrUnion helps (de-)serializing polymorphic classes.
member.remarks:
The abstract base class XdrUnion helps (de-)serializing polymorphic classes. This class should not be confused with C unions in general. Instead XdrUnion is an object-oriented construct which helps in deploying polymorphism. For examples on how to use this, please take a look at the "ACPLTea Java Library" package, which is also available from www.acplt.org/ks. As a sidenote, the serialization scheme implemented by XdrUnion is only a question of getting used to it: after serializing the type code of the polymorphic class, the variant part is serialized first before the common part. This behaviour stems from the ACPLT C++ Communication Library and has been retained for compatibility reasons. As it doesn't hurt, you won't mind anyway.
To use polymorphism with XDR streams, you'll have to derive your own base class (let's call it foo from XdrUnion and implement the two methods XdrEncodeCommon(XdrEncodingStream)
and XdrDecodeCommon(XdrDecodingStream)
. Do not overwrite the methods XdrEncode and XdrDecode!
Then, in your foo-derived classes, like bar and baz, implement the other two methods XdrEncodeVariant(XdrEncodingStream)
and XdrDecodeVariant(XdrDecodingStream)
. In addition, implement GetXdrTypeCode to return an int, uniquely identifying your class. Note that this identifier only needs to be unique within the scope of your foo class. Converted to C# using the db4o Sharpen tool.
member.author: Harald Albrecht
Jay Walters

member.name: M:NFSLibrary.Rpc.XdrUnion.GetXdrTypeCode
member.summary: Returns the so-called type code which identifies a derived class when encoded or decoded.
member.remarks: Returns the so-called type code which identifies a derived class when encoded or decoded. Note that the type code is not globally unique, but rather it is only unique within the derived classes of a direct descend of XdrUnion. If foo is derived from XdrUnion and foo is the base class for bar and baz, then the type code needs only be unique between bar and baz.
member.returns: Type code identifying an object's class when encoding or decoding the object into or from a XDR stream.

member.summary: Encodes -- that is: serializes -- an object into a XDR stream in compliance to RFC 1832.
member.remarks: Encodes -- that is: serializes -- an object into a XDR stream in compliance to RFC 1832.

member.remarks: Decodes -- that is: deserializes -- an object from a XDR stream in compliance to RFC 1832.

member.name: M:NFSLibrary.Rpc.XdrUnion.XdrEncodeCommon(NFSLibrary.Rpc.XdrEncodingStream)
member.summary: Encodes -- that is: serializes -- the common part of an object into a XDR stream in compliance to RFC 1832.
member.remarks: Encodes -- that is: serializes -- the common part of an object into a XDR stream in compliance to RFC 1832. Note that the common part is deserialized after the variant part.

member.summary: Decodes -- that is: deserializes -- the common part of an object from a XDR stream in compliance to RFC 1832.
member.remarks: Decodes -- that is: deserializes -- the common part of an object from a XDR stream in compliance to RFC 1832. Note that the common part is deserialized after the variant part.

member.summary: Encodes -- that is: serializes -- the variant part of an object into a XDR stream in compliance to RFC 1832.

member.name: M:NFSLibrary.Rpc.XdrUnion.XdrDecodeVariant(NFSLibrary.Rpc.XdrDecodingStream)
member.summary: Decodes -- that is: deserializes -- the variant part of an object from a XDR stream in compliance to RFC 1832.

member.name: T:NFSLibrary.Rpc.XdrVoid
member.summary: Instances of the class XdrVoid represent (de-)serializeable voids, which are especially useful in cases where no result is expected from a remote function call or no parameters are supplied.
member.remarks:
Instances of the class XdrVoid represent (de-)serializeable voids, which are especially useful in cases where no result is expected from a remote function call or no parameters are supplied.
Please note that this class is somewhat modelled after Java's primitive data type wrappers. As for these classes, the XDR data type wrapper classes follow the concept of values with no identity, so you are not allowed to change the value after you've created a value object. Converted to C# using the db4o Sharpen tool.
member.author: Harald Albrecht
Jay Walters

member.name: M:NFSLibrary.Rpc.XdrVoid.XdrEncode(NFSLibrary.Rpc.XdrEncodingStream)
member.summary: Encodes -- that is: serializes -- a void into a XDR stream in compliance to RFC 1832.
member.remarks: Encodes -- that is: serializes -- a void into a XDR stream in compliance to RFC 1832.

member.name: M:NFSLibrary.Rpc.XdrVoid.XdrDecode(NFSLibrary.Rpc.XdrDecodingStream)
member.summary: Decodes -- that is: deserializes -- a void from a XDR stream in compliance to RFC 1832.
member.remarks: Decodes -- that is: deserializes -- a void from a XDR stream in compliance to RFC 1832.

member.name: F:NFSLibrary.Rpc.XdrVoid.XDR_VOID
member.summary: Static XdrVoid instance, which can be used in cases where no data is to be serialized or deserialized but some ONC/RPC function expects a reference to a XDR-able object.
member.remarks: Static XdrVoid instance, which can be used in cases where no data is to be serialized or deserialized but some ONC/RPC function expects a reference to a XDR-able object.
